Chenail Indian Day School
Cornwall Island East Indian Day School

Dear Mr. Bonnah:

I have just received a letter from Miss Comeau advising me that she will accept the position of senior teacher at the Chenail Indian Day School. Before writing further to her, I wish to know if you have heard whether the Sisters of St. Ann can give favourable consideration to my letter of June 24. If the Sisters accept the Chenail School, I presume that you would like to have me offer Miss Comeau the Cornwall Island East School.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Mr. T. L. Bonnah,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Box 987, Cornwall, Ontario.
July 15, 1948.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Superintendent, Indian Agency,
P.O. Box 987, Cornwall, Ontario.

Chenail Indian Day School.

Reference your 6-1 (33) of July 9th.

It will not be possible to delay much longer with regard to advising Miss Comeau of her appointment at the Chenail School.

In fact if we do not hear from the Sisters of St. Ann within the next two days, it is my intention to advise Miss Comeau to report for duty on September 1, 1948.

If we do not take this action we are likely to be subjected to severe criticism in that we have previously indicated to Miss Comeau that we were considering the acceptance of her services.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

BFN/HM.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

ATTENTION: Mr. B. F. Neary.

Referring to your file 33-3-1 E., July 6th, please be advised that I have not, as yet, received any word as to whether or not the Sisters would accept the Chenail School. At the present time, the local Sisters are away and will not return, I understand, until around the 12th.

Regarding the above, if the Sisters accept this school, I would not consider it advisable to have Miss Comeau take over the Cornwall Island East School as Miss Helen Francis should receive priority. Undoubtedly, when you wrote your letter you had forgotten about Miss Francis.

Cornwall Island East Indian Day School.

Dear Miss Pearson:

I have now been advised that authority can be obtained for the hiring of teachers past the age of sixty-five up to March 31, 1949.

It is our intention to request authority to hire you for the remaining three months of the 1948-49 academic year. Please find attached salary letter advising you of your appointment as teacher at the Cornwall Island East Indian Day School. If you wish any further detail concerning this school, I would suggest that you write to Mr. T. L. Bonnah, Superintendent, St. Regis Indian Agency, P.O. Box 987, Cornwall, Ontario.

Yours sincerely,

Superintendent of Education.

Hyndford, Ontario.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of Aug. 12 received today.

I am unable to accept your kind offer of teaching in Cornwall Place East Indian Day School since I have accepted a position in Joseph's Residential School in Spanish, Ont., and hope to start there soon to begin on Sept. 7, 1948.

May I state I regret being unable to take Cornwall if it causes you any inconvenience. I am greatly indebted to you, and to Mr. Bowden for your exceptional courtesy and consideration while I sought employment as teacher in an Indian School. I am indeed grateful.
I hope I give satisfaction to those in charge in Spanish, and if not that age-extension continues so that I may apply to you once more for a school.

Yours, very respectfully,

Mary Learson.

Bernard F. Neary,

Charge: Indian Affairs
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 25th instant, your file 338-1 (E), concerning the Cornwall Island East School. I do not know of any teacher at the present time who is willing to take over that school although I have interviewed several. Teachers in Cornwall schools, like many other large centers, can get away with teaching only one grade or perhaps two at the most and, consequently, frown on any school where they have eight grades to teach. I don't think it is the location of the school so much as the number of grades. I have no doubt but that, had we a set-up on Cornwall Island similar to the one in the Chenaile, we would have no difficulty in getting teachers.

Insofar as advertising for teachers is concerned, it would seem advisable to advertise in papers that are more apt to reach teachers leaning towards rural schools. While we could try the Cornwall Standard-Preacher, it might also be advisable to advertise in Kingston, Pembroke and Smith Falls. It is just possible we would have some response from teachers desiring a change at Christmas. I might mention also that the Ottawa Citizen and Journal has a large coverage not only in the Ottawa Valley but also throughout Stormont and Glengarry. The Montreal Star has an exceptionally large coverage in Stormont County.

T. L. Bonham,
Superintendent,
St. Regis Agency.

Further to Agency correspondence of the 12th instant re advertisement for a teacher for the Cornwall Island East School.

A letter has been received from Miss Sarah Jane Clark, 1090 Willibrord Avenue, Verdun, Montreal 19, P.Q. She has a Quebec Superior Diploma of Pedagogy with first class honours. Reference your 6-1 (33) of November 12 and 13.

We are pleased to note that you have received a number of applications for the position of teacher at the above school.

As soon as all applications are received we can assess their relative ability and experience and decide the appointment. I would suggest that November 24 be picked as a deadline date for the receipt of these applications in your office. You can then forward them here for a final decision. If it is at all possible for you to interview any applicants you will doubtless arrange to have this done. December 3, 1948.

Dear Miss St. Pierre:

We have been able to obtain the services of a qualified teacher at the Cornwall Island East Indian Day School. However, there are two other vacancies which we require to have filled after the Christmas vacation.

One of these is at the Pic Indian Day School which is three and one half miles from Heron Bay, Ontario on the C.P.R. Transcontinental Railway. This is a one-room school and there are some twenty children enrolled.

The second vacancy is at the Seine River Indian Day School near Crilly, Ontario. Unfortunately, this is a rather isolated school and we would prefer sending a male teacher to teach. In any event, I would be glad to hear from you if you are interested in either of these two positions.

I regret that we could not classify you as a Grade 2 teacher unless you produced evidence of holding a Teaching Certificate. Your starting salary as a Grade 1 teacher without any certificate and any experience would be $102. a teaching month with free house, fuel and light.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Florence St. Pierre,
Lemieux, Ontario.

Miss Margaret MacNulty,
31 Hall Ave., E.,
Renfrew, Ontario.

Dear Miss MacNulty:

I have received your letter of December 6 and note that you wish to return your Retirement Fund cheque to our Chief Treasury Officer in view of the fact that you anticipate returning to our teaching service. This will be quite in order, and I would be glad to hear from you also as to whether you are ready to accept another teaching position.

We have appointed a teacher at the West Bay School recently and have only two vacancies for Catholic teachers at the present time. One of these is at the Seine River Indian Day School in the Fort Frances Agency, and the other is at the Pic Indian Day School in the Fort Arthur Agency. Could you please let me know whether you consider either of these suitable and if you wish any further details.

I am pleased to hear of your recovery and hope that we may be able to find a suitable position for you in the very near future.

Very sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Mr. Henry:

Today I received a cheque covering the superannuation I paid in, but as I really want to stay with the Indian Dept., I would like to leave that amount standing until I again resume teaching.

I have quite recovered from the allergic condition and may I state here it was just the second attack in twenty years. I found, however, that Mr. Chisholm and others were also victims.

I liked the children and parents at Cornwall Island and it was unfortunate that I had to leave, due to conditions.

I hope you can assure me that I will again be given an appointment when a suitable one comes up.

Thanking you, I am,

Sincerely,

Margaret MacNulty.
December 10, 1948.

Dear Miss O'Leary:

I have just been informed by long distance by Mr. Indian Superintendent Bonnah that Miss S. Clark, teacher at the above school, has submitted her resignation.

Unfortunately we can only guarantee you employment at this school for the months of April, May and June, 1949. We have another teacher in mind and your continued employment there would depend on whether she accepted it or not. However, we would do everything possible, if your work is satisfactory at Cornwall Island East, to place you in another of our Indian schools in Ontario. Dear Mr. Bonnah,

I recently received an acceptance to medical school, and only this weekend finally decided to take it. I have been trying to be accepted for two years, and since this may be the only acceptance I receive, I must therefore tender my resignation in order to be there (Switzerland) for the opening of classes. Classes start in April, so I must leave Canada at the beginning of April.

I hope this news will not inconvenience you too much, for you and everyone else on the reservation, have been most kind and obliging during my stay.

I did intend to complete the term when I started for I did not know this university had a spring class.

Sorry for the inconvenience this action will likely cause you.

Sincerely,
Sarah Jane Clark.

Dear Sir:

Pursuant to Departmental instructions, I visited St Regis agency on August 22nd to assist the Acting Indian Agent, Mr. G. Leslie.

While at the agency I was informed that there are about forty children on the East end of Cornwall Island who have never attended school. The Indians are anxious for their children to have the advantage of an education but are unable to have them attend school owing to the distance. This situation is causing much unfavourable comment amongst the adjoining white municipalities and some arrangement should be made whereby these children will be given the opportunity to obtain an education.

Gibson Armstrong.

Moved by Angus Bomaparte and seconded by Peter Day that the Council request the Department to build a schoolhouse at the east end of Cornwall Island, on property which will be donated for that purpose by Peter Day or Jake Francis.

The Motion was carried unanimously.

Referring to Resolution No. 1, that the Council request the Department to build a schoolhouse on the east end of Cornwall Island, if funds were available for this purpose, I would recommend that the Department approve of this resolution.

G. Leslie,

Ottawa, January 22, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to a resolution of the St. Regis Council, held on December 3rd, last, requesting the Department to erect a school building at the east end of Cornwall Island, to accommodate approximately 46 children of school age, who reside there and find it too far to walk to the present school on the island.

In this connection I have to say that an item has been included in our Estimates for the next fiscal year to provide the funds required to erect a suitable building for school purposes. However, I am not aware at this time whether same will be approved by Parliament at the present session. I would request that you again bring this matter to the attention of the Department towards the end of April, next, by which time we will be aware if funds for the purpose will be available or not.

Your obedient servant,

February 6, 1935.

Memorandum:

MR. ORR,-

Cornwall Island East New school building with teacher's living quarters - $4,500.

The above amount is provided in the Estimates, 1935-36, for the erection of a new school building, with teacher's living quarters, on the east end of Cornwall Island. The building will require to accommodate 40 children. There should be small cloak-rooms for boys and girls. It would also be necessary to include outside toilets - one for boys and one for girls. The school building will require living accommodation for the teacher.

Regarding a site, at a meeting of the Council, on December 3, 1934, in a resolution requesting the establishment of the school, it was stated that the property for a site would be donated by Peter Day or Jake Francis. It would require approximately one acre - minimum amount 3/4 acre; and it should be level, with good drainage, and, as it will also be necessary to have a well for water purposes, same should be obtained at a reasonable depth.

If you require any further information, I would be pleased to either furnish or obtain same. I understood, from our conversation yesterday, that you would make arrangements for a suitable site.

Dear Sir:

I might add that there is two weeks pay due the labourers.

Sir.-

Ottawa, February 19, 1936.

Dear Sir,-

With reference to your letter of the 12th instant, you may arrange for the construction of a book cupboard and a wash bench at the Cornwall Island East Indian Day School.

In connection with your letter of the 7th instant, please let me have a list of the articles which you consider absolutely necessary for the teacher's residence, also their approximate cost. On receipt of this information, the Department will be in a position to decide what amount can be allowed. As soon as the articles authorized by the Department are supplied, the teacher, Mr. Chisholm, should reside in the teacher's residence.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

The teacher says that the playground is too small. Sir,

Referring to your letter regarding the offer by Jake Francis of more land to enlarge the grounds of the Cornwall Island east day school.

When I visited the school on the 19th inst., Mr. Chisholm informed me of Mr. Francis' offer, without mention of provisory conditions. We talked the matter over, and while the grounds are at present large enough for the playing about of school children, additional land would give more space which would be available for providing a field large enough to be used for the playing of baseball or lacrosse, which is game mostly played in the district, and I am sure the youth of the Island would appreciate suitable grounds.

If the Department decided to accept Mr. Francis' offer, it would be as well if he was allowed to cultivate and graze his cattle on the land until it obtained a good level state, which could be done more expeditiously without a surrounding fence.

Mr. Francis has spoken to me about securing work in connection with the school, and I informed him the Department would be advised his services were available, where such were needed.

Any additional land acquired would necessarily be on the west side as the well is on the east side, with Mr. Francis' land just beyond.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,-

Please inform Jake Francis that the Department appreciates his offer but it is considered that the grounds at this school are sufficiently large and, therefore, we are not prepared to accept his offer at the present time.

Yours Truly,

Dear Sir,

The Architect of the Department, when visiting your Agency, early in the summer gave instructions that the outside painting required on the day school recently constructed at Cornwall Island was to be completed.

It was understood that you would purchase the material and that Indian labour would be employed.

Kindly advise if this work has been done.

Yours very truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

D. P. McNaughton, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Sir-

With reference to your letter of the 10th inst., regarding the painting of the Cornwall Island east day school, I may say that I was on the point of corresponding with the Department on this matter. The school and out buildings has received a coat of white paint, over the priming coat which was pretty well absorbed into the wood. The painting was held over pending the recovery of Jake Francis (who had been ill) as it was understood he was to be given an opportunity to do this work. As the Doctor advised Francis should not undertake this labour, the work was done, on his behalf, by his father and brother, who have done a fair job, but I have to advise that another coat will be required to give a good finished appearance, as the wood was too dry to apply enough paint at one coating.

If I have your permission I can get ahead with this work especially as Francis has the necessary (borrowed) scaffolding on the spot.

Your Obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

In reply to the last paragraph of yours of Nov. 24th., last, re quotations for materials to repair the teacher's residence at Cornwall Island East Indian Day School, I enclose for your perusal estimates from the firms of Hodgins Lumber Co., and Emard Brothers of Cornwall, Ontario.

In addition Mr. Chisholm advises that it will be necessary to purchase one mattress. One can be purchased with 1 year guarantee for a price of $15.95. The teacher also advises that a coal and wood stove will be required (not a gasoline stove) and this can be purchased for a price of $69.00 with reservoir or at a price of $79.00 with reservoir and heating oven.

With regards to estimates for repairs to the residence I would like to point out that it would be of great benefit to have this work done. The room in question was never completed and regardless of what teacher might be at this school the finishing of this room for a kitchen would be very practical.

The present mattress at the residence is in bad condition with the springs showing through in several places and it would be advisable to have a new one.

I would recommend the above for your consideration.

February 9th., 1943.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA, Can.

Your records will show that since the Fall of 1938 children from the Cornwall Island West Day School were transported weekly to the Cornwall Ild East school for manual training and domestic science. The arrangement has proven very satisfactory.

Transportation since that time has been provided by Paul Caldwell, Indian of Cornwall Island West at a cost of .75¢ per trip. This man is very reliable but for some time he has complained about the small scale of wages for this service. You realize that this ties a man and team up from 1.00 PM until approximately 4.30 PM. To get another Indian to do this for .75¢ is out of the question and even at twice that rate it would not be possible to get someone as reliable. Mr. Caldwell has advised us this date that unless we would be in a position to set a rate of $1.50 per trip he would have to discontinue this service as apart from his everyday farm work he is getting many extra calls for his team.

As the west-end school is crowded to capacity it is not possible to hold these classes there and at any rate it would be too bad to make any change in the present policy just now as everything is working out so smoothly for children and pupils.

I would recommend authorization be granted to increase the rate to $1.50 per trip. Your reply is awaited.

D.P. McNaughton
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

MR. HOEY

Re visit to the St. Regis Schools for the purpose of studying the crowded situation in the Cornwall Island Day School and the water and heating situation at the teacher's residence in the village of St. Regis.

XX XX XX

CORNWALL ISLAND EAST DAY SCHOOL

I visited for a few hours at this school and had children pass the Standard Achievement Test in Reading. The object was to demonstrate to the teacher the method of administering diagnostic tests so as to deal with the difficulties of the pupils in a more systematic manner.

The interior of this school should be redecorated as soon as conditions permit. There is some difficulty in the drainage of the basement where Manual Training is taught to the boys. There must have been a few inches of water in the centre the day I was there. It appears to be due to an obstruction in the drainage system. This situation could be easily remedied, I believe, by the use of sewer rod either from the interior or from an excavation from the exterior. This would entail only labour; however, this is rather difficult to obtain on the Island today.

XX XX XX

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

TEACHER'S RESIDENCE

I visited the teacher's residence three or four times to study the conditions from various angles. Mr. Buck, from the Engineering Branch, was at the Agency Wednesday afternoon May 17. I took the liberty to ask him to look at the building, the water situation and the heating plant. His time was very limited as he had to make a complete study of the Agent's Residence and he could not devote the time necessary to recommend any solution to the above mentioned problems. I thought, however, that even a casual glance might be helpful to him, if it were necessary to revisit the Agency at some future date.

The Indian Agent had quite a difficult task endeavouring to accommodate Mr. Buck, the Doctor, Inspector Wescott, and myself. I wish to express my appreciation for the cordial way in which he accomplished his duty.

The exterior of the teacher's residence is in need of paint. The windows and doors need adjustment. The walls, except those below the windows that are protected by the verandah, are streaked with water. This apparently occurs after every rain. I would suggest that the window casing be removed to determine the cause of this trouble. The spaces should be packed with oakum and caulked before putting on the casing and caulked again after the casing has been put in place. Grey caulking should be used as this kind may be painted. An Indian, a painter by trade, is available, provided he is hired in time. He expects 50¢ per hour for his services.

(over)
This work is mostly a question of labour which I am left to understand is rather difficult to obtain mostly due to the isolation of this reserve.

The furnace is of sufficient capacity to take care of the heating requirements of this building. It is a Högla, No. 122, 23½ inch fire pot and has a capacity from 12,000 to 16,000 cubic feet. This furnace was installed in 1927 when the building was erected and according to the file has not been touched since its installation. A complaint made after the first winter stated that the furnace did not give sufficient heat but apparently nothing was done as no reply appears on our files. The hood of the furnace is of a horizontal type; hence the pipes rise immediately above the furnace and run practically parallel to the ceiling of the cellar. Moreover, three of the hot air pipes are only 7 inches in diameter. One of these 7 inch pipes heats two rooms on the second floor which have a capacity of approximately 1000 cubic feet each. This would be more easily remedied if it were not for the ducts encased in the wall, which I presume would have the same area as the pipes leading to them. While I was in Cornwall I interviewed Mr. Edward Parker, plumber, who is willing to check up this furnace, install a new one (the radiator may be burnt which seems to be the chief defect of this type of furnace) for the approximate cost of $300. I believe, this could be done more cheaply, as he has given, in all probability, the highest that it might cost. I told him that we would inform him through the Indian Agent when to proceed with this work.

The water situation may be solved by several solutions. The most practical, I believe and the one I would attempt in my own home under similar conditions, would be to tap the casing of the present well approximately twenty feet below the surface which would be ten feet below the water level and run a 1½ in. pipe below the frost to the teacher's residence to be connected with the present pumping unit. I believe, that at this time it is practically impossible to obtain a gasoline engine to drive the pump. The present pump in the teacher's residence could be used until a motor driven pump can be obtained.

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

RE: Cornwall Island East School

I do not know whether you are in possession of any plans of the lay-out of the teacher's quarters attached to the above school. If so, you will notice that the sleeping quarters comprise one rather small room upstairs with a low ceiling which forms the peak of the school. In other words, this one-room sleeping quarters is what we might consider as being the attic of the school with the exception that it is the extension of the school which comprises the living quarters.

Such a condition as outlined above does not altogether present a very healthy atmosphere and, while it might be tolerated if it could be possible to always find an unmarried teacher, it certainly could hardly be considered as providing proper sleeping accommodations for a family no matter how small.

This situation might be remedied for the benefit of not only the present but future incumbents of this school with an expenditure of less than $300.00. It is proposed, with your permission, to raise the roof on one side and thus provide suitable sleeping accommodation. The figure mentioned above will, I believe, cover all materials and labour required. Insofar as most of the interior work, the present teacher, Mr. Chisholm, would be very glad to do this himself. I am attaching a sketch giving a rough idea of what is proposed. It would be appreciated if authorization could be granted to proceed with this necessary change without delay as at the present time, it is possible to locate a carpenter who can do this work.

JUL 9 1947

F. L. Bomah,
Indian Agent.

Referring to your file 33-3-5 (W.T. 1), July 12th, last, I might say that in view of the change in teachers made at the Cornwall Island East School, I did not go ahead with my previous recommendation. I understand from the present teacher, Mr. Ryan, that the residence is satisfactory as is without further alteration.

In view of the above, I will not proceed, at this time, with any alteration to the building but I would like authority to construct new steps to the class room from the outside just as soon as I can obtain sufficient materials. The entrance to the class room from the outside is very poor and much of the lumber has rotted. I would also like authority to expend around $30.00 for paint to decorate the interior of the residence part of the building. This has not been done for quite some time, apparently, and needs redecorating.

I have a small amount of money on hand from the accountable advance forwarded for the construction of the chimney at the Cornwall Island West School and if you will forward me an additional accountable advance in the amount of $75.00, I think I can have both jobs above described carried out. I can not, at this writing, give you an estimate on the materials required for the repair or renewal of the entrance steps but it is not expected the cost of materials for this particular item will run in excess of $75.00.

Your early reply is awaited.

[Signature]

A. L. Bowman,
Indian Agent.

I am enclosing herewith three tenders received for wiring the Cornwall Island East School and Residence and supplying fixtures from the following Cornwall firms:

1. "Elco" Electric - total price $290.00 plus $30.00 additional for 60 amp. wire service for electric range in Residence.

2. Cornwall Electrical Sales - total $302.80 with additional amount of $40.00 for heavy duty range service.

3. Campbell's Electric - total $308.95. No additional amount quoted for 60 amp. service but would suggest an amount of approximately $35.00 be added.

It would appear from the above that the quotation submitted by the "Elco" Electric, which includes all inspection fees, is the better price submitted. It is not known whether you would like to have a 60 amp. service installed in the event you would want facilities for an electric range at a later date. If so, it would appear that it would be well to have this done at the same time. You will note the price of this firm is very reasonable quoting the total of $320.00 for the complete installation of fixtures with heavy duty service.
I might add that "Elco" Electric did the job for us at the west end school on Cornwall Island in a very satisfactory manner.

Already the power company have the poles installed as far as the east end school and will be putting up the wires shortly. There is no doubt that if we could have this work done now it would be an added inducement to obtain the services of a qualified teacher for this school. Your reply is awaited.

The new building which comprises a regulation-size classroom, basement and living quarters of 3 rooms for the teacher is a credit to the Department of Indian Affairs who have provided so well for the educational welfare of all the children on the Cornwall Island Indian Reserve. Adjoining land is being used by the pupils at the present time, and this is likely to be the cause of dissension. It would be more satisfactory to acquire an additional ½ acre, which can be secured at little cost according to information supplied, and it is suggested that a fence be erected that would enclose the school grounds.

GENERAL REMARKS

Under this heading the Inspector should report upon the general management of the school and offer any suggestions for improvement he may wish to make.

With the enrolment as follows, - Form I Jr. 28, Form I Sr. 5, Form III Jr. 8, at least 2 or 3 years will be required to get the school in reasonable shape. The present teacher gives indications of being able to bring this about in due time.

In reporting on his inspection of the Cornwall Island East School on May 26, Inspector Matthews refers to the irregular attendance of three children. He claims that this is due to parental neglect and suggests that the services of the R.C.M.P. be obtained. General Comment:

I took Grade 1 for reading and had them at the board for word recognition and number work. They did very well. Most of them could write their own name and address.

I felt that the teacher was doing as good a piece of work as could be expected under the existing conditions.

The five pupils in grade 8 all expressed the desire to go on to grade 9. I told Mrs. Gant that they were retarded and would have to do a lot of work before the end of the year if they were to go to high school.

St. Regis, Que.
October 26, 1944

Mr. R. A. Hosy, Supt. Welfare & Training

For the past number of years it has been customary for the children of the Cornwall Ild. W. school to go down to the Cornwall Ild. East school for homemaking and manual training classes. Mr. Chisholm took the boys for manual training, and Mrs. White took the girls for domestic science. In view of the fact that Mrs. White has a considerable number of girls this year in her class, and Mr. Chisholm has only a few, it would seem advisable for Mrs. White to conduct the girls' class in her own school and send only the boys down to the East school for manual training.

The only problem this would raise is the matter of the few girls in Mr. Chisholm's school who would not be able to get up to the West school for domestic science. At present we would be unable to arrange for transportation for these few girls up to Mrs. White's class. Nevertheless it is believed that the benefits offered by this change in arrangement are great enough to warrant adopting it.

Please let us have your views in this matter.

T. L. Hannah
Indian Agent
Ottawa, November 9, 1944.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, St. Regis, Quebec.

In reply to your letter of October 26th, the Department approves the plan which you suggested, re the co-operation Manual Training between the Cornwall Island schools.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
St. Regis, Que.
November 9, 1944

R. A. Hoey, Esq., Supt. Welfare & Training

With further reference to our letter of October 26, regarding arrangements to be made for manual training and home making for the boys and girls of the Cornwall Island schools, the following arrangement is being tried.

The girls of the Cornwall Island West School will take domestic science with Mrs. White in her own teacher's residence, as soon as this is completed, and equipped. The boys will go down to the East end school where they will have manual training with Mr. Chisholm's class of boys. The girls from the East School will go up to Mrs. Deer's Homemakers' Club on Wednesday afternoon when the boys are having manual training, and there they will be taught sewing.

This arrangement will go into effect next week, so there can be no report as to its success as yet, but it is felt that this should solve our problem for these two schools.

With further reference to our letter of November 9, regarding plan for manual training and home economics training at the Cornwall Island Schools, this plan has been in operation for part of this month. Contrary to expectations, it has not worked out to the benefit of the pupils, as far as taking the girls of the East school to Mrs. Deer's Homemakers' Club on Cornwall Island is concerned. This club already has an enrollment of some fifteen women who come each week, and in a small home like Mrs. Deer's it has proved to be an imposition to expect her to take on nearly a dozen pupils from the school in addition.

Consequently, this plan has been discarded for the East school, and Mrs. Chisholm has kindly consented to give these girls instruction in home economics in her own residence while Mr. Chisholm takes the boys downstairs for manual training, one afternoon a week.

If this step is approved by your office, it will be necessary to have authority to expend a sum of about $20 for Mrs. Chisholm to buy the needed materials for these classes for the balance of the year.

His application is enclosed in case that you would like to contact him with a view to placing him on some other Reserve. There is no guarantee, however, that he will go.

Regarding the Manual Training Instructor's position, it is proposed to leave this vacant for the time being and Mr. Chisholm will continue to teach for the next academic year at least at the Cornwall Island East School. Dear Mr Scott:

Pursuant to our conversation of the 16th inst., I submit the following for your further consideration:

The Anglican Missions on the East shore of James' Bay and northward to the Eskimo Mission at Whale River were founded by the late Bishop Horden, who, as a missionary arrived at Moose Factory in the year 1851. The Anglican Church has been in occupation and until a few years ago in sole missionary occupation of that whole area; the result being that the entire Christian native population dwelling at, or dependent upon, such posts as Rupert House, Fort George and Whale River became members or adherents of the Anglican Church.

This state of affairs continued until a few years ago - I think about seven - when Roman Catholic agents took up their residence at Fort George and proceeded to erect a church with a large building suitable for Indian residential school purposes. These, and similar activities at Akulavik, N.W.T., were brought before, to the notice of the officials of the Department. (see, for example, my letter to you dated Oct. 12th. 1926.)

Among the results of these representations was the ruling set out in your letter, dated Dec. 28th. 1927, and addressed to the Rev. Dr. Westgate - reading as follows:

"It is thought that the denominations should respect the zones of interest which have been established and not encroach upon them by the extension of missionary effort upon which a demand for separate educational institutions might be afterwards based. This view seems entirely reasonable, and in future the Department will not recognize requests for aid to educational..."
institutions unless by pre-arrangement, and assistance must not be expected for institutions which encroach by the extension of missionary effort upon territory already provided for."

Another result of the consultations held in the years following the close of the war, was set out in the following letters:-

"The Hon'ble Charles Stewart,
Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Department of the Interior,
OTTAWA,
Ont.

April 17th. 1922.

Dear Sir:-

Please accept this expression of my appreciation of the sympathy and kindly courtesy with which you received the recent Deputation in connection with the Indian Residential Schools.

The decisions then agreed upon are, from the standpoint of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada, most urgent. I, therefore, respectfully submit my understanding of them in writing, as follows:-

1. It is agreed that the provision of buildings for Indian Education, in the form of Residential Schools, is a direct and sole responsibility of the Dominion Government.

2. It is agreed that it is the purpose of the Dominion Government to provide, as soon as may be possible, the buildings required.

3. It is agreed that, pending provision of the said buildings, the Dominion Government will provide the money necessary to enable the Church Authorities concerned to carry out urgent repairs on the buildings owned by them and used for the purposes of Indian Residential Schools.

An acknowledgment and confirmation of this letter will deeply oblige,

Your obedient servant,

(sgd) S. Gould,
General Secretary M.S.C.C."
Ottawa, April 21st. 1922.

"Dear Canon Gould:-

I wish to acknowledge your favour of the 17th instant, setting forth your understanding of the principles discussed at the meeting last week, when I had the pleasure of becoming acquainted with the representatives of the Church Missionary Societies that are doing educational work among our Indian wards.

You may rest assured that it is my purpose to urge upon the Government the desirability of providing, as soon as possible, the residential school buildings that are needed to successfully carry out the work. As an interim arrangement, the Department of Indian Affairs will endeavour to have voted the funds necessary to enable the Church authorities concerned to carry out the urgent repairs on the residential school buildings owned by them.

I have to thank you for your expression of appreciation, and I wish to assure the Church representatives of my continued interest in this connection.

Yours very truly,

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D. (sgd) Chas. Stewart,
General Secretary Superintendent General
Missionary Society,
Church of England in Canada,
131 Confederation Life Bldg.
Toronto, Ont."

I quote also from your letter to me dated May 26th. 1925:-

"I have your letter of the 2nd. instant, relative to repairs to church owned Indian residential schools. At an interview with church representatives, in April, 1922, the Honourable the Superintendent General stated that the Department would endeavour to keep the church owned buildings in a state of good repair, until such time as new buildings could be provided. Mr Stewart's letter to you of the 21st. of the same month reads in part as follows: "As an interim arrangement, the Department of Indian Affairs will endeavour to have voted the funds necessary to enable the church authorities concerned to carry out the urgent repairs on the residential school buildings owned by them."

The intention behind the words quoted seems to me to be perfectly clear, and I am pleased to carry it out."

To revert to Fort George I find that our need of an Indian Residential School at that point was included in the list contained in my letter to you dated Oct.18th. 1924. A definite
Application for such a school was made at an earlier date, I believe, by the Bishop of Moosonee.

The urgency which this need has now assumed is shown by the following extract from a letter, dated Oct. 26th, 1931, from the Principal of our Indian Residential School at Moose Factory:

"I have had to refuse about 30 children admission into this school this summer. Our quota with Government grant is for 30 pupils as you know, but owing to deaths amongst our people including the Wynne family of Albany, I felt constrained to take extra children into the school so that last June I had 35 children in residence. Since the school opened after the summer holidays I have had 34 children in residence all the time and have again had to refuse others admittance. It is heartbreaking to have to do this, especially when the R.C.'s are begging and worrying our people to let our Protestant children go to their Roman Schools. Rev. Morrow, of Rupert's House, reports that six of his children have now been taken away by the R.C. Priest to the Fort George School and he further reports that some of the Indians at Rupert's House have stated to him that if they cannot get their children in our school at Moose Factory, they will have to let more of their children go to the R.C. School at Fort George."

This action of "the R.C. priest" appears to be in direct contravention of the ruling set out in your letter to me dated December 30th, 1921, from which I select this quotation:

"It has been decided to adhere more strictly to the intention of the Act as set forth in section 10[1] as follows:— "No Protestant child shall be assigned to a Roman Catholic school or a school conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, and no Roman Catholic child shall be assigned to a Protestant school or a school conducted under Protestant auspices." In the future, children from Protestant and Roman Catholic homes will be considered eligible for admission respectively, to Protestant and Roman Catholic schools only. We rule that wards of the Department of Indian Affairs should be admitted only to institutions conducted under the auspices of the church to which the parents themselves belong."

Under the circumstances just outlined, coupled with the inability of the Department to proceed, for the time being, with the provision of "the residential school buildings that are needed to successfully carry out the work," (Vide Mr Stewart's letter quoted in full above), the Executive Committee of this Society decided, at its recent meeting, that our long-established interests in the region on the eastern side of James' Bay must be protected, and the demands of our people there for residential school education be met by the erection, this coming summer, at Fort George of an Anglican Indian Residential School. The Executive Committee further appropriated for this purpose - from one of the invested funds of the Society - the sum of $20,000.00. (twenty thousand dollars.)
In connection with this decision and appropriation, I now beg submit this written application:

1. That provision be made in the estimates of the Department of Indian Affairs, for the forthcoming parliamentary year, for the payment of per capita grants for the pupils of an Anglican Indian Residential School at Fort George. The number of pupils to be thirty, at a per capita rate of $250.00 (two hundred and fifty) per annum.

2. That pursuant to the principle expressed in the letter of the Hon'ble, the Superintendent General, quoted in full above, and in accordance with the precedent of certain refunds made to another church, the Department agree, at the earliest convenient date, to refund (without interest) to the General Treasurer M.S.C.C., the sum for capital expenditure (Viz; $20,000.00) mentioned in the next preceding paragraph.(i.e. at the foot of preceding page.)

I respectfully urge both these requests upon your kind and sympathetic attention. I desire to emphasise, nevertheless, early favourable decision upon the first (the per capita grant) in order that we may proceed with our plans to send in the large amount of material required for the erection, next summer, of an Anglican Indian Residential School at Fort George.

Believe me,

Yours very faithfully,

SG-G

General Secretary M.S.C.C.

Dear Sir,

I have just returned from a hurried trip down the Mackenzie to the Arctic coast, and find that our General Secretary, Canon Gould, has left for England. As he will not return for some weeks I am venturing to write to you direct regarding the question of per capita grants for the new School at Fort George, James Bay. I understood before I left for the North that you were good enough to give favourable consideration to this matter, and that it was to be included in the Supplementary Estimates submitted by you to Parliament. I have no information as to what was finally decided by the Government in this connection, and would be very grateful to you if you could see your way to let me know at an early date, in order that I may be guided in connection with this matter.

Perhaps I should explain that this Indian Residential School will come under the Arctic Mission, of which I have special general charge, and therefore the matter presses upon me at the moment more than upon any other officer of our Church.

I regret that owing to pressure of business during the closing session of Parliament it was not possible for me to secure an interview with you, but I hope that at some future time I may have that honour.

Dr. McGill,

Re: Fort George Anglican Indian Residential School.

Information on file indicates that the Church of England, in the summer of 1932, erected a building for residential school purposes at Fort George. We have no details regarding the size and type of the building. Venerable A. L. Fleming, Archdeacon of the Arctic, in June, 1932, requested that a per capita grant be provided for the children in attendance, and, in reply, he was informed that the Department was unable to include in the supplementary Estimates for Indian Education a grant towards the cost of constructing a building at this point but that, if the Missionary Society proceeded with the building and pupils were enrolled, payment of per capita allowance would be given consideration upon receipt of school returns. I may add that returns, showing attendance during the March and June quarters, 1933, have been received. They show an attendance of 16 girls only. Dr. Tyrer, Indian Agent, states that the school is well equipped to take care of 60 pupils.

The Indians on the east coast of Hudson Bay are not in treaty; the half-breeds there live the Indian life and do not speak English.

In September, last, Rev. Canon S. Gould, General Secretary, M. S. C. C., visited the Department and requested that a per capita grant be provided for 40 children. He stated that the Church had erected a school and were not at that time asking the Department to contribute towards the cost of the building but wished only to receive a per capita grant for the Indian children in attendance.

If provision is made, it will be necessary that the Appropriation for Indian Education be increased next year by the amount of the grant allowed.

For a number of years, the Department has provided a grant towards teacher's salary in conducting a day school at this point and also has paid accounts for fuel and janitor service and rent of building for school purposes.

Sir,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to the Fort George Indian Residential School.

The Department has no objection to the holidays being taken from June 15th to August 15th. I would point out, however, that grant is only allowed for forty-three (43) days' holidays each year; consequently, if the school begins holidays on June 15th, the Principal, in preparing the June quarter return, may ask grant for the full quarter for each pupil who has been in residence. This will mean that fifteen (15) days of the holiday period have been allowed on the June quarter grant.

When preparing the return for the September quarter, grant should be requested for each pupil who has been allowed home on holidays and who returned to the school on August 15th for 74 days (balance of holidays - 28 days; August 16 days; and September 30 days). In other words, in preparing the September return, grant should be requested for the actual number of days each pupil is in residence during the quarter plus 28 days, the balance of the holiday leave.

Dear Sir:

The Rev. T.E. Jones, B.A., who has filled the Principalship of our Society's School at Fort George for five years, will retire from that position next July, and our Society will appoint, subject to the approval of your Department, the Rev. Bertram Samuel Greene, to take his place.

Mr. Greene, who is 30 years of age, is a graduate in Theology of Wycliffe College, Toronto, and in addition to the training he received there, he has had very considerable experience in institutional work. The following quotation from a testimonial furnished by the authorities of one of the institutions where he worked, will speak for itself:

"On an average we have one-hundred and forty girls and boys, a great variety of dispositions to deal with. Mr. Greene through the grace of God gave each one love; he taught them to sincerely read their Bibles; to love all that is noble and good and to pray with reverence. By example he has taught them that the better things in life bring real happiness and joy and he has been unsparing in his efforts to teach them clean healthy sports. In fact since he has come to the Home, it has been a different place. . . . . . . . .

I have been in charge of this Home for nearly twenty years, and never had children looked to God with such confidence as the children are doing today. God has given us such splendid Clerical Friends in the past, who have helped such a lot, but never with such results as Mr. Greene has had. The children love him so dearly it will be a terrible parting."
As Mr. Greene has had a business training we consider ourselves fortunate in being able to secure his services for the important position in question, and I sincerely trust that his appointment may meet with the approval of your Department.

He is engaged to be married to an Honor Graduate in Sociology of Toronto University; and it is my understanding that he will be married in the very near future.

In reply to your telegram—Re—closing schools.

As there is a plane leaving here in a few minutes I thought it best to reply by mail—

Res. School education for Indian children in this Agency does a lot of harm as it takes the children away from their normal life just when they should be learning to hunt, so that when they are discharged from the school they know nothing about making their living in the normal way for the Indians in the north.

I have not found any Indian that sends his children to the Res. School to get an education, the reason is always that the child will get fed and clothed by the school.

The money spent by the Department for the Res. Schools I consider could be spent to much better advantage in other ways—such as feeding and clothing children, looking after pregnant women and the general welfare of the Indians.

The Indians complain that the children do not get the proper food in the schools—you can understand this as the Indian likes the country food best. The children in the schools are not improving in health as they should and I think it a mistake to take the Indian away from his regular mode of life.

There are other reasons which could only be transmitted to you in a personal letter.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyner

Minutes of the One Hundred and Forty-sixth Session of the Northwest Territories Council held in the office of the Commissioner on Tuesday the 8th December, 1942, at 11:30 A.M.

9. Eastern Arctic Matters -

(1) Fort George School, P.Q. - admission of Eskimo children

The Secretary reported that Dr. T.R. Westgate, Secretary of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada wrote to the Department under date of the 23rd October, 1942, from Winnipeg, as follows:

"The Principal of our Fort George School, P.Q., has informed our Commission of some Eskimo families living along the eastern shore of the Hudson and James Bays, and he desires to know if the children of school age in these families may be admitted to his school on a per capita grant earning basis.

"While it is my understanding the Dominion Government has ruled that the status of the Eskimo and Indians are identical, I will be obliged if you will let me know if the Eskimo children mentioned, up to 10 in number, may be received as per capita grant earning pupils into our Fort George School."

Dr. McGill pointed out that 50 pupils is the quota for the residential school at Fort George and the last report received showed an attendance of 40 pupils. He remarked that the admission of 10 Eskimo children would bring the quota up to the number agreed upon. The Chairman thought Dr. Westgate was justified in asking for the admission of Eskimo children so long as the quota of 50 pupils was not exceeded. The Chairman agreed with Dr. McGill that the same procedure would be followed in Quebec as in the Northwest Territories with respect to the payment for the education of Indian and Eskimo children. Mr. Cumming pointed out that no provision had been made in the estimates for the education of Eskimo children at Fort George. He referred also to a remark made by Reverend Father Plourde during one of his visits to Ottawa that 15 Eskimo children were ready for admission to schools at Fort George. Father Plourde had been asked to submit full particulars but no further information or correspondence has been received to date.

(a) Fort Simpson, N.W.T.

The Secretary reported that in a letter dated 5th September, 1942, His Lordship Bishop Sovereign requested financial support for St. David's School at Fort Simpson, N.W.T., despite the fact that the attendance for the quarter ended 31st December, 1942, was less than the average required in order to earn the grant.

St. David's Mission School was opened in 1901 and has been in operation almost continuously since that time. The Northwest Territories School Ordinance provides for the payment of special grants to any school whether organized according to law or not. The established policy has been to support day schools in southerly or Indian Territory to the extent of $200.00 per annum - $50.00 per quarter. The only departure has been the cases of schools at Fort Smith and Yellowknife where qualified teachers are employed, the Alberta curriculum taught and exceptional circumstances prevail. Payment of the grant is based on submission of quarterly returns and provided the average daily attendance is five or more.

Although it is the custom to require an average daily attendance of five or more in order to earn the grant, nevertheless in view of special conditions and circumstances which exist at times, and realizing the need for maintaining educational facilities at all strategic points, the Department has on occasion allowed a portion of the grant when the average attendance was less than five.

In 1933-34 the average attendance at St. David's school was below the required figure but the Minister of the day approved of one-half the regular grant being paid, that is $25.00
per quarter or $100.00 per annum. Apparently the same situation is again developing at Fort Simpson as it is noted from the last return that the total attendance is only five made up of three white and two half-breed children.

It was moved by Mr. Cumming, seconded by Mr. Daly, that in view of the fact that St. David's is one of the oldest schools in the Mackenzie District and the desirability of maintaining two mission schools in settlements where there are children of both denominations and the distinct possibility that the settlement of Fort Simpson will expand rapidly when the road and other transportation facilities now under construction are completed and the need for schools will be even much greater than at present, that if St. David's Mission School is kept open for the benefit of whatever pupils attend, one-half the regular grant be paid, that is $25.00 per quarter or $100.00 per annum. This action will not create a precedent. Carried.

Dear Canon Dixon:

It is my understanding that you will discuss this afternoon with certain officials of the Department of Munitions and Supply the desirability of taking steps, in the immediate future, to rebuild the Fort George Indian Residential School.

The records of this Branch indicate that this building was destroyed by fire on January 26, 1943. It had at that date an enrolment of 50 pupils, for which we allowed grants at the rate of $200.00 per pupil per annum. It is unnecessary to state that these grants will again be paid just as soon as the new building is in operation. Provision has been made in the 1943-44 estimates for such payments.

In view of the large number of Indian day and residential schools destroyed by fire in recent years, only one or two of which have been rebuilt, accommodation at Fort George is very much needed, particularly in view of the fact that this is the only institution designed to meet the needs of the Indians who are members of the Anglican Church in that area.

Should the officials of the Munitions and Supply Department require additional information, I want them to feel free to communicate with me by phone.

The Canadian Reindeer Herds

Expenditure - Departmental expenditures up to 31st March, 1937, pertaining directly to preliminary investigations, the establishment and maintenance of the Reindeer Station and the purchase of the original reindeer stock from Alaska amounted in round figures to $350,000. Since that time the yearly cost of maintenance has averaged about $21,000. The following are the official figures for the past four years:

Fiscal Year 1940-41 - $16,387.25
" 1941-42 - 20,075.22
" 1942-43 - 26,209.98
" 1943-44 - 23,656.17 - (This item is subject to adjustment when final figures available)

Revenue - Departmental receipts in respect of the reindeer industry consist of the proceeds of meat and hides sold from the main herd. These are surplus products after providing for direct relief, donations to missions and meat for the local medical officer and camp purposes. The sales are made to residents of the district, native and white, who are in a position to pay for these products. The proceeds of meat disposed of in lieu of wages are included in the sales. The following are the revenue returns for the past four years:

Fiscal Year 1940-41 - $574.15
" 1941-42 - 1,924.90
" 1942-43 - 3,469.70
" 1943-44 - 6,707.60 - (This item is subject to adjustment when final figures available)

Utilization of Reindeer Products - The original stock of 2,370 reindeer from Alaska delivered to the Canadian range east of the Mackenzie delta in March, 1935, had increased by the summer of 1943 to more than 9,000 heads, in three herds - 6,157 deer in the main herd on the reserve and 3,173 animals in two herds under native management near the Anderson and Horton Rivers. During the development of the reindeer herds, meat and hides are provided for the use of those directly engaged or connected with the herding work. In addition meat is available for direct relief and large quantities are supplied each year to the mission hospitals and residential schools in the Akivik area as a contribution toward the maintenance of these institutions for the benefit of the natives. More than 1,000 carcasses from the main herd have been supplied free to the missions. These represent a value at local prices of about $23,000. The hides are used for local purposes with a number of surplus hides being made available for shipment to needy Eskimos in the Eastern Arctic.

In the case of native herds the natives in charge are allowed to take meat, hides, sinews, etc., from surplus stock for their own use or to sell or exchange for necessary cash, furs, supplies or services. Any cases of destitution in the vicinity of the herds are to be supplied with reindeer products on a basis of replacement from the main herd.
Grants - aid -

The N.W.T. Administration pays the following annual grants in support of the various schools:

- Residential schools - $400 per annum.
- Some day schools in Mackenzie District - $200

In addition to the regular grants the N.W.T. Administration also furnishes school supplies.

The Northwest Territories Council has approved payment from the Territorial Liquor Fund of the cost of correcting examination papers of the Fort Smith and Yellowknife Public Schools.

Curriculum taught -

The Alberta Curriculum is taught in most of the schools of the Mackenzie Districts. In the Eastern Arctic where the population is almost exclusively Eskimo the Missionaries teach a few elementary subjects including reading, writing, drawing, etc.

Maintenance of children in residential schools -

The Northwest Territories Administration pays $200 per annum for each of the destitute or orphan children maintained in the residential schools. These children are admitted under special application form certified by the parent or guardian, the local representative of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and the District Agent. A certificate of health is given by the resident Medical Officer.

Schools in Eskimo Territory of Quebec -

As the Administration of Eskimo Affairs has been vested in the Northwest Territories Administration provision has been made for the payment of grants (on the same basis as those of the N.W.T.) toward the maintenance of residential and day schools operated within Eskimo Territory of the Province of Quebec.

At the present time there are two residential schools at Fort George, P.Q., one operated by the Anglican and the other by the R.C. Mission. Provision has been made for the maintenance of 10 pupils in each school @ $200 per annum, each, and in addition the schools will receive the regular grant for residential schools of $400 per annum.

Anglican residential school at Fort George, P.Q., destroyed by fire. Until now school constructed pupils are maintained in the residential school at Moose Factory.

Biscuits for Eskimo children attending day schools in Eastern Arctic -

The food problem at Fort George Church of England school was very difficult during the past winter. It was partly due to insufficient supplies and lack of some essentials. During the winter country game was very scarce. A severe epidemic resembling 'flu developed in the area during February, March and April. This strain of illness plus lack of fresh food and nothing such as milk, canned tomatoes or other canned fruit and vegetables was enough to bring many of the pupils below their threshold of sufficient nutrition. As a result when I examined them this summer, twenty-five out of the fifty, showed very evident indications of Scurvy. Sufficient concentrated vitamins were sent from my office to the school to treat these children and the principal was strongly urged to increase his stock of food supplies and to include such items as milk and canned tomatoes. These children do not receive milk as a routine. They never see fresh fruit and vegetables. Everything they eat is canned or is made up of staples such as flour and other cereals plus seasonal fresh country food which is not always sufficient even for the time it is available.

Thos. J. Orford, M.D., C.M.

Honourable and dear Sir:

Re: St. Philip's Indian Residential School,
Fort George, Que.

I beg to make application on behalf of our Administration for an increase in the authorized pupilage at the above school. I may say that Anglican missionary work in this area was commenced in 1852 and educational work was carried on in a simple manner for a considerable period. In 1932 a residential school was built by the Church and thirty-five pupils were authorized, this number being increased to fifty in 1938. In 1943 this school was destroyed by fire and in view of the great need for such an institution our Missionary Society expended a considerable sum in constructing the present building in 1944. The Bishop of the Arctic (Rev. A.L. Flemming) was asked to plan the building and supervised its erection. He was under the impression that the Department had authorized an increase of pupilage to eighty but when the school was opened the number was restricted to fifty.

The basis of our request lies in information recently received from the principal of our school to the effect that he has the names of one hundred and eighty-six baptized Anglican children of school age in the area. By reason of the fact that we have been unable to admit more than thirty pupils, a number of Anglican children have been admitted to the school established by the Roman Catholic Church contrary to Clause 10, Section 2 of the Indian Act. Our principal claims that material is being assembled for the enlargement of the other school and this can be for no other purpose than admission of a larger number of Anglican pupils. In these circumstances we feel justified in asking that the authorized number of pupils be increased to seventy-five and I trust that this will meet with your approval.

Commending this matter to your kind consideration,

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) H.A. Alderwood,
Superintendent.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Indian Residential School Principals

On behalf of this Administration and with the endorsement of the Executive Committee of M.S.C.C., I beg to make the following nominations:

The Rev. Canon H. S. Shepherd, B.A.,
as Principal of St. Phillip's School,
Fort George, Quebec.

The Rev. G. W. Fisher, L.Th.,
as Principal of St. Alban's School,
Prince Albert, Sask.

The Rev. D. C. Wickenden, B.A.,
as Principal of the Indian Residential School, Sioux Lookout, Ontario.

Canon Shepherd was formerly in charge of our school at Shingle Point in the western Arctic and took charge of All Saints', Aklavik, after its construction. He came out on furlough after a long term of service and has latterly been acting as Eskimo Missionary at Port Harrison, Quebec. As we expect a few Eskimo pupils at Fort George, his knowledge of the language will be invaluable.

Mr. Fisher had a long and successful term at Lac la Ronge and was transferred to Sioux Lookout only a year ago. We regret that the state of health of Mrs. Fisher has made it necessary for him to be placed within easy reach of medical care, and at his request we have favorably considered the change suggested. Mr. Fisher has a good knowledge of the Cree language and will have many points of contact with the pupils attending Prince Albert.
Mr. Wickenden has been acting Principal at the Gordon's School since the destruction of Lac la Ronge. He is a fully qualified teacher and prefers this appointment to that at Gordon's in view of the fact that he is more interested in the academic side of the work than the practical, and it would appear likely that for some time to come there will be the necessity of structural changes at Gordon's.

We can confidently commend these three men for the positions indicated and trust that their appointment may be definitely confirmed. It is proposed that all shall reach their schools during the summer in good readiness for the re-opening at the beginning of September.

Thanking you and with kind regards, I remain

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Alderwood

Superintendent

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With reference to your letter of the last inst., No. 72-05, re a grant of $400.00 for any repairs that might be required at our Fort George School, I beg to state that the most urgent need at this School is the enlarging of the main school building, and I would strongly recommend that this grant be used in purchasing some of the material required for that purpose.

You may recall that this building was provided out of Church funds, and it was the understanding of our Bishop (Bishop Fleming, of the Diocese of the Arctic) that it had a capacity of 80 pupils. His understanding in the matter was subsequently found not to be shared by officials of the Department, who considered the air space provided insufficient for so large a pupilage. The only way to meet the wishes of the Department in this respect is to enlarge the School, and in view of the heavy expenditure which our Church has already made on this and the other buildings at this centre (including a church, a residence for the principal, a mission house, storeroom, etc.) it seems to me but reasonable to ask that some assistance be given us in the enlargement of the main school building.

I have before me a fairly comprehensive list of the materials required for this project, and I have received one estimate on the cost of the same, delivered at Moosonee. The total cost up to that point is approximately...
$2500.00, and to this would have to be added the freight for the rest of the way, and the cost of building. It is probable that the total cost will amount to about $3,500.00.

While I think it likely that our Society would be willing to provide part of this amount if an assurance were given that an increase in the pupilage would be allowed, I still feel that there is a just claim on the Indian Affairs Branch to give us some help in providing additional accommodation for the children of their Indian wards at this remote centre.

It is now nearly ninety years since our Church began work at Fort George, and it is my understanding that practically all of the Indians in that and the surrounding settlements are members of our Church. We have done our utmost to help them and the Government in providing for their physical, mental and spiritual welfare, but our resources are limited, and especially under prevailing world conditions.

If the Department will agree to allow the $400.00 mentioned in your letter to be applied in the way suggested, and can make a further grant of at least $2,000.00 next year for the same purpose, in addition to granting an increase of ten in the pupilage, I will endeavour to persuade our Society to find the balance.

As the cuts in the grants which we consider were arbitrarily imposed during the years 1932-38 inclusive, meant a loss in revenue to our Society of approximately $142,000.00, and as we will suffer a further loss in revenue of at least $15,000.00 a year so long as the ruling remains in force that the pupilage is to be reduced to 92.24% of the number originally agreed upon, I think you will see that we cannot reasonably be expected to provide the full amount required for the desired enlargement of the main school building.

As the last boat proceeding to Fort George this year is scheduled to leave Moosonee Sept. 5th, it is now too late to forward any of the building material at that time. I trust, however, that the arrangement I have suggested above may be adopted, and steps taken to have all the required material go forward by the first boat from Moosonee next year.

I will ask the Principal of our School at Fort George to furnish me with a revised detailed list of the minimum quantity of all materials required, and could let you have this shortly after it reaches me by the mid-winter mail, possibly towards the end of February or the beginning of March.
Thanking you in advance for any help you and your Department of Government may be able to give in this urgent and important matter,

Believe me,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23rd instant, addressed to Mr. Phelan, of this Branch.

It was my hope that I might have an opportunity of having a personal discussion with you or someone representing your Commission, with respect to the operation of a number of Church of England residential schools.

When I visited Chapleau a few weeks ago, I learned that the water supply there was scarcely adequate to meet the normal domestic needs of the institution and that it would be wholly inadequate in the case of fire. The estimated cost of installing an adequate water system at the Chapleau school is $3,000. No provision has been made in the estimates of this year, however, for this work. It was also impossible to include in this year's estimates the sum necessary to proceed with the rebuilding of the Carcross Residential School, and the water supply and sewage systems at the Lac La Ronge School are matters that have also been left in abeyance, owing to lack of funds.

Do you consider it really wise that an attempt should be made by your Commission to extend

I have just received your letter of the 17th inst. #72-0-3, and note that although the December Quarter return for our Fort George School has reached you, the return for the preceding September Quarter has not yet arrived. Your letter No. 160-2 of the 30th June, 1941, enclosed statement showing amounts provided for repairs and improvements. Dear Mr. Hoey:

In your letter of the 30th ultimo number 160-2, you stated that the sum of $550.00 would be available for repairs, improvements, and the purchase of new equipment at Fort George School this year.

In a letter dated July 11th, and just received from the Rev. H. E. Hamilton, the new Principal at this school, he states that he and the Rev. B. S. Greene who has just retired from the Principalship of that school, had agreed that the school's most urgent need was a boat possibly about 30 feet long, and fitted with a marine engine for transporting children to and from their homes to the school, and in bringing in sick Indians for treatment in the hospital, etc.

Mr. Hamilton states that he knows a native who is an excellent boat builder, and that he could build the boat during the coming winter if our Commission guaranteed the provision of an engine.

I have not yet had time to ascertain the cost of a suitable engine, but I am writing for the specific purpose of learning if you will agree to allow the $550.00 appropriation to be applied towards the cost of purchasing and shipping the same.
Mr. R.A. Hoey - 2 July 23.

While it does not seem likely that the engine could be purchased in time to be shipped before navigation of James Bay closes this summer, it could be purchased and paid for before the end of March next, and sent forward as soon as navigation opens.

Trusting your Department may authorize the expenditure of the $550.00 in the way suggested, believe me,

faithfully yours,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Fort George C.E. Residential School dated July 22, enclosing requisition for supplies for the school.

Many of the items mentioned on the Principal's list are not usually supplied by this Branch as they are considered replacements. I refer in this regard to a request for can openers, frying pans and dishes.

We have supplied at other schools a reasonable amount of furniture when funds were available and you may, therefore, advise the Principal of the Fort George School that we will allow him an amount of $300.00 toward the purchase of furniture for the Principal's residence and the staff rooms. I believe he should arrange for the purchase of furniture to the above amount and he will be able to have the furniture reach Moosonee in time to be taken to the school before winter starts. When he has made the purchase you should certify the account and forward it to this office, when payment of the amount of $300.00 will be allowed.

Yours truly,

Dr. T.J. Orford,

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

On July 23rd last I wrote to you to ascertain if the grant of $550.00 available for repairs, improvements, etc., at our Fort George School this year, could be applied towards the purchase of an engine for a boat which we hoped to build for that school this winter.

Shortly after despatching my letter I received from the Rev. Principal Hamilton a copy of the list of requirements for his school which he had forwarded through Dr. Orford, the Indian Agent. I immediately despatched to you a telegram dated July 30 cancelling my request that the grant be made available for the purchase of an engine, as I felt that the items on Mr. Hamilton's list were of greater urgency, and that precedence of claim on the grant should be given to those items instead of to the engine formerly requested.

I have just now received from Dr. Orford, a letter dated August 23rd, and with it a copy of the list of requirements he had received from Principal Hamilton and which he had forwarded to you. He states that your Department will allow the sum of $300.00 toward the purchase of furniture for the Principal's Residence and the Staff rooms, and he asks me to "arrange for the purchase and shipment to Moosonee as soon as possible".

By the same mail I received your letter of the 24th inst. #44-6-5 in which you stress the importance of having supplies purchased through your Purchasing Branch, and it is for this reason that I do not feel justified in placing any order for the items required at Fort George without a specific authorization from you.
As the last boat of the season will leave Moosonee on September 21st, it is important that an order be placed at once by your Department for all the items given on the enclosed list, on the understanding that our Commission will meet any cost over and above the $300.00 which you are allowing. If we wait to ascertain the items your rules would permit you to buy, the last boat of the season may have gone before we could secure the others.

As Dr. Orford appears to understand that he had authority to ask our Commission to make the purchases it will be appreciated if you will let me know by air mail or wire if his understanding is correct. If I do not hear from you by the end of this week I will conclude that you are acceding to my request to purchase all the items on the list, and that you will advise me of the cost over and above the $300.00 which you are providing.

If the purchase is to be made through your Purchasing Branch the goods should be consigned as follows:

Rev. H.B. Hamilton,
Principal, Anglican Indian School,
Fort George, Que.
c/o Hudson's Bay Company,
MOOSONEE, Ont.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
