Dear Sir:

In the matter of general payment of the salaries of Night Watchmen at our Society's Indian and Eskimo Residential Schools at Aklavik in the N.W.T., and Fort George in Quebec, an order was given to the respective Principals of these institutions to submit monthly requisitions for the same through the local Indian Agent. In this connection I beg to state that I have just received a letter from the Rev. Canon H.S. Shepherd, Principal of our Aklavik School, in which he points out that it is impossible for him to forward such requisitions at the end of each month because of infrequency of the mails. He also points out that by sending the requisition through the Indian Agent at Fort Norman long delays are inevitable, and reminds me that one of the requisitions he sent through the Indian Agent at Norman did not reach Ottawa until six months after it had been despatched.

Owing to the distant location of our Aklavik and Fort George Schools, and the absence of frequent mails, it has seemed to me that the most satisfactory way of dealing with the question of payment of the Night Watchmen's salaries at these Schools, will be for our Commission to submit quarterly requisitions, and in the hope and expectation that you will agree with this opinion, I am enclosing herewith requisitions in triplicate for the salary of this agent at each of the two schools mentioned, for the quarter ending December 31st last, and will send similar requisitions at the end of March next for the March quarter and the month of April.

Should there be any further specific information which you may require in connection with these requisitions, I will gladly endeavour to supply it during my visit to Ottawa the beginning of next week.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Secretary of the Commission.

March 27, 1944.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I beg to confirm my telegram in regard to the installation of a water system in this school, and our request that the appropriation of $300.00 for the fiscal year about to end should be allocated to this object. I deeply regret that there has been a serious oversight in our office which accounts for our belated request. In assuming my new duties I was advised that matters relating to property and equipment were the concern of the Assistant Secretary and Treasurer, and I have normally worked on this basis, although we naturally confer where matters have to be decided upon. I now find that in the past my predecessor attended personally to the list of requirements forwarded to your Department by the Principals. In the present instance, Mr. Hamilton has written on several occasions but the matter has not been attended to owing to the misunderstanding as to responsibility.

Our Principal tells us that Dr. Orford has been keenly interested in the matter of a water system, and that he discussed it with you in Ottawa and found your mind fully in accord. As a matter of fact, we in this office know very little about the construction of the new school as it was placed by our Missionary Society Executive in the capable hands of Bishop Fleming. Certainly we are warmly in favor of the suggestion that a water system should be installed at the time the school is being built. On grounds of health, protection against fire, and the convenience of those who work in the school we are entirely in agreement that such a system should be installed. In spite, therefore, of the fact that we have not been able to submit definite specifications I trust that it may still be possible to apply this $300.00 appropriation towards the cost of the necessary supplies. I take it the cost will be considerable but am confident it can readily be justified.

We wired to your Agent at Moose Factory this morning and he may be communicating with you shortly.

Awaiting with interest your word, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H. A. Elderwood
Secretary.

Dear Dr. Orford:

Re Water system at Fort George.

I beg to confirm telegram sent you this morning and trust that we are not too late in securing the desired appropriation from Ottawa. I may be allowed to explain that we have no record in this office of receiving any letter from you in this connection, but have discovered two letters from our Principal which were not followed up owing to a regrettable misunderstanding in this office. The construction of this new school is something which has not been at all in our care as it was entrusted to Bishop Fleming by our office in Toronto. We have not been advised as to many of the details, but I take it that Mr. Hamilton is in a position to know that no water system has been planned for. Certainly we endorse the suggestion and are confident that on grounds of health, fire protection and the welfare of staff and pupils it is one of the most important items in the construction of a school. We are not in a position to say what equipment is needed, but trust that you will have accepted our general approval and will be able to secure the appropriation from Ottawa before the fiscal year ends on the 31st of this month.

Thanking you for your interest in this matter and regretting our inattention, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood

Dear Mr. Phelan,

In further reference to your letter 160-2 dated August 30th, 1945, and in confirmation of my telegram sent this morning, I now beg to enclose receipted invoices in quadruplicate from the Winnipeg Paint and Glass Co. Ltd., totalling $300. This covers material which has been purchased to construct six storm porches at the above school. The new building was erected without any such protection and during the winter the need was found to be very great. There are four entrances on the ground floor and in time of blizzard the snow banked up heavily against them. Furthermore, the school was not provided with eaves-troughing and when the snow melted considerable ice formed in front of the doors and in some cases prevented them from opening. The trouble was specially bad in connection with the two fire escape doors in the upper storey. For lack of protection these also tended to become banked up with snow and seal. Our Principal, therefore, urged that porches should be constructed in all cases and we trust the trouble will now be remedied.

I regret the exceeding lateness of this request, but may say that our Principal has been asking for so many things that it was difficult to know what was most urgent. There was a long delay in the early part of the year during which no mail was received from Fort George and our Principal left the school by plane in great haste a few weeks ago owing to the tragic death of his wife. We have had difficulty in communicating with him and I trust that it will be possible to apply the amount of $300 to cover this necessary material.

Thanking you, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Secretary.

Moose Factory May 14th 1934

Mr. J.D. Sutherland  
Department of Indian Affairs,  
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I will again bring the attention of Mr. Jones at Fort George to the matter of the admission and discharge reports. There has been no return mail from Fort George since Feb 27th.

Nora Tamook NO-017 I believe is still in the school but as I had notified Mr. Jones that I thought she was an Eskimo he seems to have concluded the same so left her name off the authorized list.

As I informed Mr. Jones that I would inspect all the pupils in August and September he is perhaps holding the form for that reason. (Philip Cox, no-33)

I received another freight shipment for Leslie Garrett at Trout Lake which I will forward. If you have ordered more for this school it might be better to change the shipping directions.

Yours truly,

W.L. Tyre
Agent.
Ottawa, July 28, 1934.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the June quarter return of the Fort George C. E. Residential School.

The application form for Philip Cox, No. 33, requested in official letter of May 4th, last, has not yet been received. I would appreciate receiving this as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Philip Phelan,
For Supt. of Indian Education.

W. L. Tyre, Esq., M.D.,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory, Ont.

Ottawa, September 5th, 1935.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo, with reference to the Fort George Indian Residential School.

The Department has no objection to the holidays being taken from June 15th to August 15th. I would point out, however, that grant is only allowed for forty-three (43) days' holidays each year; consequently, if the school begins holidays on June 15th, the Principal, in preparing the June quarter return, may ask grant for the full quarter for each pupil who has been in residence. This will mean that fifteen (15) days of the holiday period have been allowed on the June quarter grant.

When preparing the return for the September quarter, grant should be requested for each pupil who has been allowed home on holidays and who returned to the school on August 15th for 74 days (balance of holidays - 28 days; August 16 days; and September 30 days). In other words, in preparing the September return, grant should be requested for the actual number of days each pupil is in residence during the quarter plus 28 days, the balance of the holiday leave.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dr. W. L. Tyfer,

Ottawa, March 9, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The returns submitted by the Fort George Indian Residential School have not been prepared in the manner required by the Department, as the names of both the boys and girls were included on the one page. We have, therefore, prepared a return showing the manner in which the names of the boys and girls at present in residence in the school should be listed on future returns and the register numbers which should appear opposite their names. Separate sheets should be used for the names of the boys and girls.

In the event of the discharge of any of the pupils at present in the school, the register numbers opposite their names should be dropped and not used again.

A new number should be given to each pupil on admission, and the next boy that enters the school should be numbered 59 and the next girl 661.

Please inform the Principal of the contents of this letter and, if he does not prepare his return in the manner desired by the Department in future, you should return the same to him for correction.

Ottawa,
October 19, 1936.

Dear Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to return the September quarter return of the Fort George C.E. Residential School.

With regard to the boys you will note that the names have not been entered on the return consecutively according to number. This should always be done.

When a pupil is discharged his number should be dropped and should not again appear on the return. A new number should be given to each new pupil upon entrance.

As the Department allows grant for 92 days holidays the Principal should, in preparing the September return, request grant as follows:

1. For those pupils who were in the school at the time the holidays began and who returned promptly within two months of that date grant should be requested for 92 days.

2. In the case of pupils entering the school for the first time during the September quarter grant should only be requested from the date of admission to the end of September.

3. For a pupil who was allowed on holidays at the beginning of the holiday period and did not return within two months of that date grant should only be requested for the number of days actually resident in the quarter plus the number of holidays to which the pupil was entitled.

W. L. Tyref, Esq., M. D.,
Indian Agent,
Moose Factory,
Via Moosonee, Ont.
In the case of the Fort George School I note that the holidays began on June 15. Consequently, 15 days of the holiday leave was allowed the school in paying the June quarter per capita allowance. This left a balance of 47 days for the September quarter. Therefore, if a pupil allowed out on holidays on June 15 did not return to the school until August 20 the Principal should, in preparing the September quarter return, request grant for such pupil for the period August 20 to September 30 plus 47 days holiday leave.

Part payment of the per capita earnings for the quarter ended September 30 is being forwarded to the Treasurer of the M.S.C.C. and the balance will be paid when a properly completed return is received by the Department.

For your convenience I enclose extra copy of this letter which you can forward to the Principal.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

DEATH OF PUPILS.
January 25, 1946.

Dr. Percy Moore,
Indian Medical Services,
Department of Health & Welfare,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Dr. Moore; Re: St. Philip's School, Ft. George

In a recent letter from our Principal the following paragraph occurs and I feel that it should be passed on to you:

"One of our pupils died from the meningitis yesterday morning. Miss Scott had sent a wire about this boy to Dr. Orford some time ago, and the reply was that he had been active there four years ago when examined. However, in spite of that fact, Dr. Orford allowed him to be admitted to the school this year again. He had formerly been in school before the fire. Is there any way in which pressure could be brought to bear upon the authorities to have the Indian Agent examine the school children on his visit to the Post? Since I have taken over the School this has never been done. Now that the pupilage will be more or less the same for a few years, an examination at any time would be a big help to us. This death was an unfortunate occurrence, as the boy was of the Inlanders, and they have just started to put children in to the school again. I sincerely hope this incident will not have any serious effect upon the people."

I trust that we may look forward to the time when pupils entering the schools on James Bay are examined as carefully as appears to be the case now at Aklavik. I feel confident that this is your desire and doubtless when the new institution is established at Moose Factory many improvements in the health situation may be expected.

I am looking forward to another visit to Ottawa during the latter part of February and hope to have the pleasure of seeing you then.

With kind regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

H.A. Alderwood
Secretary.
MEMORANDUM

Feb. 16, 1946.

To: Dr. P.E. Moore

Re: St. Philip's School, Ft. George

Rev. H.A. Alderwood's letter bears out my point made on more than one occasion that residential schools in isolated areas constitute a health hazard until we can gather sufficient personnel to carry out immunization and X-ray survey. No reliable physical examination will discover tuberculosis in a child unless it is a gross lesion. The development of tuberculous meningitis can be, and frequently is, rapid in an apparently healthy child where X-ray has not been available to demonstrate an actual or potential chest lesion.

The particular case mentioned by Rev. Alderwood was referred to me by radiogram last fall by the nurse in charge at the C.of.E. Ft. George hospital, and from symptoms described it appeared to be a meningitis. This diagnosis - made by radio - was purely tentative and considered probably as tuberculous in origin due to the course of the disease which proceeded to death in January. Referring to my file on the boy, I had examined him on one or two occasions during previous summer visits and not on any occasion considered him a definite case of primary tuberculosis though I did list him as a suspect and for further examination. Under present conditions such an examination reveals only gross lesions.

Certainly at time of entrance to school the case did not show symptoms referable to a developing meningitis. If he had, he would have been placed in hospital.

Rev. Alderwood's letter should certainly be considered insofar as it should increase our efforts to offer adequate attention for all schools in James Bay in conjunction with the proposed medical service throughout the area.

T.J. Orford, M.D.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Reverend Father Belleau, in charge of both the Fort George and Albany Residential schools, has asked for the following improvements for these two schools:

I.--Fort George:

(1) A small outer building for implements and farm machinery 25' X 35'.

(2) Outside bake-shop 25' X 18', the oven will be constructed of second-hand bricks by one of the Brothers attached to the school.

(3) About thirty-five gallons of paint would suffice to paint the exterior of the school. The labor for painting as well as for the construction of the two buildings mentioned above would be supplied free of charge by the principal.

II.--Albany:

Accommodation for sick pupils at the Albany school is very primitive and Father Belleau suggests that Porch-Solarium, 10 feet long by 8 feet wide might be a good solution for this problem. He estimates that the cost of this structure would be between four and five hundred dollars. As in the case of the Fort George School, the principal would supply all labor free of charge.

I hope that you will be able to provide for the above improvements in the coming estimates.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Flourde, O. M. I.
November 2, 1938.

Father Belleau informs me that he received news by wireless that the laundry building of Fort George school was destroyed by fire about the 28th of September. The building is a total loss also the equipment. This equipment consisted of a gasoline engine, a washing machine, a stove, water heater and a drying rack. Although Fort George is not a government owned school, it is to be hoped that funds will be made available to enable the principal to rebuild and equip a new laundry.

(Sgd.) J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

Dear Sir,

Last year you were kind enough to supply a small washing machine for the Fort George R. C. Residential School. Up to the time this machine was bought by your Department all the washing was done by hand as well as the ringing.

If you could now supply a small drying machine it would be very much appreciated. All the Indian girl pupils who work in the laundry are taught to wash by hand but heavy washing and drying require some machinery, because otherwise the work cannot be done in the time allowed for it.

If funds for this purpose could be appropriated in the coming estimates it would be very much appreciated.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant requesting that a small drying machine be supplied to the Fort George R.C. Residential School.

At the present time I am unable to state definitely what amount will be available in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 for the purchase of new equipment at Church-owned Indian residential schools. I am hopeful, however, that some funds will be available and in that event careful consideration will be given to the requirements at the Fort George R.C. School. Please write to me again in connection with this matter about the end of April at which time you should give detailed information regarding the type of drying machine required.

Ottawa,
February 19, 1940.

EXD.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant requesting an allowance toward the salary of a night watchman to be employed at the Fort George R.C. Residential School.

Owing to present regulations we are only permitted to pay for night watchmen at those Indian residential schools where specific provision has been made for such services. No such provision has been made in the current year's appropriation for a night watchman at the Fort George R.C. Residential School and consequently I regret that no allowance can be made.

If it is possible to make this provision in the appropriation for the coming fiscal year such action will be taken but I should like it definitely understood that at the present time I can give no definite assurance that such provision will be made.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Enclosed, please find requisition of building material for our Fort George Catholic Residential School, with prices quoted by a firm who supplied material last year for that same school.

You will notice that one item has been cut off from the list, so that, with discount, the total is $799.13.

We would appreciate very much that you have this requisition filled by the Department's Purchaser as promptly as possible, in order that it may be shipped with our other supplies, in the first half of June. If the Department cannot let us have these goods delivered at Moosonee, we would prefer having them shipped with our other supplies, from Montreal, as we have been granted a rate of favor on freight for our Missions, when shipped by carload lots. It would be advantageous therefore, to have this shipment go with other Mission goods, to save on freight rates.

Your kind co-operation in procuring this material is very much appreciated, and we thank you sincerely.

Yours very truly,

+ Henri Belleau O.M.I.

Moosonee, Ont. September 15th, 1941

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I have received your letter no. 72-4-4, dated 3rd instant, regarding school material requisition for the Fort George Residential School, and I wish to thank you for it. You mention that the requisition of May 29 has gone forward to the Government Stationery Office. This is quite satisfactory.

When visiting the Fort George School lately, I was told that two requisitions had been sent, the latter to complete the first one. I am sending you the first requisition which is of course the most important, and would be much obliged if you checked up on it to see whether this or the latter requisition is the one which was sent to the Stationery Office.

I regret imposing this trouble upon you who are busy enough without having to review such things as have once passed through your hands. I trust it will not cause you too much trouble; the last shipments are about to be made from here to Fort George, and it would be too bad if by mistake they ran out of school material. Winter transport of such articles is difficult by dog-team.

The laundry machinery ordered by the Department for the Albany Residential School has not yet arrived. One of the three pieces was not available, I believe, because it was still in use and could not be delivered. But the washer and the extractor were supposed to be on hand. In two weeks, transport by navigation will be at an end here. The purchase order dated July 11, is stamped with the name of H.J. Davidson. The Agent of the Beaver Laundry, J.L.C. Lecours had quoted prices on July 7. The order is numbered 8196, File no. 39,510-15-20-1.

Thank you for your kind cooperation in this matter and many others.

Yours very truly,

+ Henri Belleau O.M.I.

Moosonee, Ont. March 17th, 1943

Mr. R.A. Hoey
Superintendent of Welfare and Training
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines and Resources
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Thank you sincerely for the telegram dated 11th instant re-requisition for the Fort George School. As you instructed, the order was immediately placed with the firm that had made the tender, in order that no delay would follow. They have been instructed to ship all material and date the accounts before March 31st.

The list of building material and equipment amounted to about $640.00, according to prices quoted by Omer DeSerres Limitée, of Montreal. I submitted this to the Department because I had understood that an appropriation of $800.00 had been made for this requisition and that this same amount would be available. The order placed with the Omer DeSerres firm amounts to $550.00, as you instructed. Must we understand that their will be a balance of $250.00 to complete the expenditure of the promised appropriation? If such were the case, we would appreciate it very much if this encumbrance or balance were spent on hard brick for chimney building at the Fort George school.

Without further writing on our part, on this subject, because of the proximity of the end of the fiscal year, if there remains the amount of $250.00, we would appreciate that the Department's Purchaser place the order for Hard Brick (not pressed), to be delivered at Moosonee, Ont.

I would be much obliged to you if you could let me know what are the last decisions and possibilities concerning this requisition for the Fort George school. Thank you for your very kind cooperation.

Very sincerely yours,

+ Henri Belleau O.M.I.
Vicar Apostolic of James Bay.
Ottawa,
March 23, 1943.

Dear Bishop Belleau:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, in which you state that you have placed the order with Omer DeSerres, Montreal, for material required for the Fort George R.C. School. I note that you are under the impression that an amount of $800.00 has been provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at this school. I regret that you were apparently misinformed regarding the amount, because the sum of $550.00 was the total provided.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rt. Rev. H. Belleau, O.M.I.,
Vicar Apostolic of James Bay,
Moosonee, Ont.

Dear Mr Hoey:

Thank you for your letter of the 23rd ultimo re-requisition for the Fort George school. Order given to Omer DeSerres Lété does not exceed $550. If by mistake, this firm sends all material mentioned in their tender or quotation, balance of account will be paid by us, provided the Department pays $550.

I had asked prices on material and not knowing at the time the exact amount, I had submitted list of material which amounted to about $640. Afterwards, on reception of your telegram, I got in touch with DeSerres and corrected my error concerning amount appropriated by Department.

Thank you for notifying me.

Yours truly,

+ Henri Belleau  
Vicar Apostolic of James Bay.

March 11, 1944.

Reverend Fr. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
University,
Ottawa.

Reverend Sir:

We have gone over your plans which were enclosed with your letter of March 1st, and we are unable to give you a very definite estimate on the wiring supplies because we do not know what type of building is to be wired.

If this is a new building there would no doubt be some changes, and if it is a building which was constructed some time ago, you might possibly want part of it in concealed wiring and some of it in open wiring. This has not been stated in your plan, and there is no mention made of floor plugs or the type of drop lights, or whether you want wall switches or pull-chain receptacles.

Therefore we have quoted porcelain pull-chain sockets and also added about 25 toggle switches in case you want to turn on lights by means of wall switches in some of the rooms. Although there may be some left over, they would be useful in some of the other buildings that you mention that might be added to this later on.

We cannot make delivery this month, but we can quote you on the material and if you want to place your order with us, or for that matter, make payment if necessary to get in before the end of your fiscal year, we could make delivery in the following month, when our next shipment of Winchargers should arrive.

Therefore, the following equipment will be necessary: Price, net f.o.b. Winnipeg

One rebuilt Delco Light Plant, Model 850 $156.00
One Model 150 Wincharger 231.20
16 Cells, 17-plate, 360 ampere-hour batteries 220.00
40-foot galvanized guy-wire tower 44.10
Wiring Supplies as per attached list, approx. 144.50
We are enclosing an illustration of the unit, also a pamphlet showing the battery. The tower will place the unit 45 feet above the ground.

You do not state whether or not you want fixtures in any of the rooms. For example, the kitchen has two lights. Would you want the regular kitchen units? These would cost about $2.00 each, net, but you would not require the porcelain pull-chain socket and the drop cord, which are already quoted. Other rooms might require some type of ceiling fixture, possibly a single or double fixture with a switch on the wall.

These are points which are not covered, also the matter of floor plugs in some of the rooms. For that reason the wiring price is only an approximate figure to which you would have to add something for the difference between the present drop cord and socket arrangement, and the fixture, which might be preferred.

You will note that we have quoted with this installation a lighting plant as an auxiliary, and therefore have quoted a 17-plate battery instead of 21-plate. Where you have an auxiliary plant it is not necessary to have the largest type of battery, because if you have failure of sufficient wind for several days, the auxiliary plant can be put into operation and the batteries fully charged. The same applies if a drain of higher than 10 amps. is required, when there is no wind and the batteries are in a semi-discharged condition. It is advisable that the batteries should have some support in such a case, and for that reason an auxiliary plant is almost necessary in an installation of this size.

We have a plant on hand at the present time, completely rebuilt and guaranteed. This plant burns kerosene or gasoline or distillate, but it is started with gasoline, preferably the cheaper grade.

We have a great many orders on hand for Winchargers, batteries, and plants. Therefore we would suggest that you place your order as soon as possible, and give us an option of delivery in April.

Yours very truly,

DICKSON ELECTRIC COMPANY, LTD.

(Sgd.) W.P. Smith, Manager.

Cher Mr Doucet,

Je prends occasion de la nouvelle année pour vous souhaiter une Bonne et Heureuse Année et des grâces nombreuses pour vous et votre petite famille.

Je dois vous dire que nous avons passé un bel automne et une bonne fin d'année. Le recrutement de notre école fut bon, de sorte que abritons encore cette année une bonne trentaine d'enfants. Nous avons plusieurs malades à notre hôpital. Je me suis bien amusé avec le Père Ethier durant les vacances jusqu'à l'an, nous avons fondé le Studio L.A.R.O.M.I nous avons travaillé à colorer quelques photos, ça semble assez facile.

J'espère que vous viendrez nous voir avant longtemps, c'est facile maintenant que la guerre est terminée. Nous avons changé de Supérieure l'été dernier, Soeur Thérèse D'Avila est avec nous au moins pour six ans. Elle a beaucoup d'expérience avec les enfants indiens.

La petite Laveuse Beatty que le Département des Indiens nous avait envoyé est brisée, seulement après 20 heures de travail. Je pense bien que c'était un manque dans la machine. Impossible de réparer ici. Cette machine est garantie pour un an. Je vous demande comment procéder pour l'envoyer, dois-je l'adresser directement au Département ou l'envoyer à la manufacture. Laissez moi cela à savoir.

Nous voudrions bien avoir un dactylographe commercial pour nos rapports d'école et d'hôpital. Nous le commanderons sur la commande de livre d'école.

Cher Mr Doucet, un gros merci pour tout ce que vous avez fait pour nous. Au sujet de l'école de jour de Fort George, a-t-il été décidé quelque chose ?

Au revoir, union de prières et sacrifices
Père Lionel Labrèche O.M.I.
Fort George, Baie James, Ont.

Ottawa, January 30th, 1946.

Dear Father Labreche:

I have taken note of your letter of the 12th instant. I was away on a tour through Southwestern Ontario for the greater part of the month of January. This is the explanation for the delay in answering your letter.

I carefully noted your two little snapshots and I guess your laboratories certainly do embellish the North to some extent.

I was very sorry to hear that your washing machine has been causing you trouble. I think the simple way of doing it would be to send this machine to the following address: Hughes Appliances Limited, Agents for Beatty Washers, 74 Rideau Street, Ottawa, Ontario. If you would be kind enough to notify me when you are sending this machine I will make it a point to examine it when it arrives and before it goes out to make sure that everything is okay.

As regards the typewriter, I think we will have to wait some time yet as these machines seem to be rather difficult to obtain at the present time.

I presume that you have received the various games that were sent some time last November.

The subject of the Seasonal School at Fort George will come up for discussion in the near future. I will then notify you of the outcome.
Please offer my best regards to Father Ethier and to the other members of your personnel. I wish you the greatest success possible in Indian education.

Yours sincerely,

A.J. Doucet,
Training Division.

Rev. L. Labreche, O.M.I.

Dear Mr. Arneil:

Enclosed please find a copy of an Invoice from Charles Ogilvy, Ltd., Ottawa, which I received last summer.

During Mr. Doucet's visit last winter to Fort George, the subject of such a machine as is listed in the Invoice came up. He seemed to appreciate our position, and seemed agreeable that we should begin to build up a small "workshop of power tools" to handle repair work, etc., such as might be necessary around the premises.

I believe, during your visit, this subject was also referred to.

Having received two copies of this invoice, I felt reasonably sure that our request had met with approval, and that this machine was shipped for our use. However, when the shipping season was over, the machine had not arrived - or so I thought. Feeling that it had missed shipment at Moosonee, I have not sent notification about it before this.

The other day the R.C. brother was up to look at our Delco, and we began discussing equipment, etc. I happened to mention receiving the Invoice for the jointer, only to find that it had gone down to the R.C. Mission on its arrival at Fort George. This was, indeed, news to me. Remembering your kind offer to be of any assistance possible, I am now writing to you to check up for me on this matter. Was this machine ordered for us, or for the R.C.? If it was ordered for us, what can be done about it at this date? I understand that they have not got the machine set up yet, but I hesitated to say anything more without first writing to enquire for definite information.

Thanking you for co-operating in this matter in the midst of your busy life, I remain

Sincerely yours,

Dear Bishop Belleau:

With reference to your letter of the 1st instant, I think the freight account to which you refer covered the shipment of a carload of cement for the Fort George Residential School.

On reviewing our file, I find that we paid $258.00 for the carload which it was understood contained 150 barrels or 600 bags.

We did not pay the freight of $199.50. The amount specifically allotted for the Fort George R.C. School has been expended but the amount provided for the Albany School has not all been spent. Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing copy of a letter received by the Railway Agent at Moosonee, insisting on having freight paid by us on the carload of cement quoted at .76 1/4 cents per sack.

On the insisting of the Canada Cement and the impossibility for the Agent to let us have the carload without payment, we paid the freight bill amounting to one hundred and ninety-nine dollars and fifty cents (199.50).

This carload of cement was sent by order of the Department to Fort Albany. I had asked for a quotation of prices direct from the Montreal Office of the Canada Cement and was told (by wire and also over the phone) that F.O.B. Moosonee, .76 1/4 cents per sack would be the price. In fact we bought cement for our own use at that price.

As delivery of the cement went to the F. Albany R.C. Residential School was made only in August, I received notice of this only when returning from the visit made to the different missions, and consequently have delayed taking the matter up with your office.

Do you think anything could be done about this matter? I believe the freight should be refunded, because some mistake must have been made somewhere about the rate or cost fob Moosonee. You showed Rev. Fr. Plourde and myself the file of the Albany School, in which file you had the Canada Cement quotation at .76 1/4 cents. This was last Spring, towards the end of the fiscal year, if I am not mistaken.

Thank you for the attention you have given and will again give this matter, and for many other services rendered.

Sincerely yours in Christ,

+ Henri Belleau O.M.I.
Bishop Henri Belleau O.M.I.

P.S. Of course, if the Dept. paid less than .76 1/4 cts a sack, owing to our paying freight, that would be reasonable; we understand that fiscal year was over when this was discovered. I see that delivery was made in July, no Aug. If nothing can be done about it, it will be alright as far as we are concerned. We'll be looking ahead next time.
Ottawa, 6 December 1946.

Ottawa,
February 19, 1941.

Reverend Sir:

In checking the December quarter return of the Fort George R.C. School the names of the following pupils appear:

No. 17 David Weetaltock
" 18 Edward "

Our records indicate that these pupils were discharged from the school in 1939. Were their names placed on the December quarter return by mistake or have they been re-admitted to the school?

The names of Louis Atrington, No. 19, and John Kanatiwat, No. 22, were shown on the September quarter return but do not appear on the December quarter return although no application has been received for their discharge. Please advise regarding these boys.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. D. Couture, O.M.I.,
Principal,
R.C. Indian Residential School,
Fort George, Que.,
via Moosonee, Ont.
À Monsieur Philippe Thibaut
Ottawa.

Cher Monsieur,

Ci-inclus les informations requises concernant les enfants mentionnés dans votre lettre du 19 février dernier.

Veuillez s'il vous plaît, excuser mon oubli à ce sujet.

Pour ce qui concerne les No. 18 et 18, ce sont des ré-admissions que je ai choisies de présenter à d'autres parce qu'ils avaient été examinés par le docteur lors de leur première admission. Ils sont toujours demeurés à l'école pensionnaire. Ils ont ainsi été présents sur les rapports à la demande du docteur parce que celui-ci n'avait pas leurs numéros.

Pour ce qui concerne les deux autres, à savoir les No. 19 et 22, ils sont arrivés de leurs vacances malades. C'est pour cette raison que nous les avons envoyés en septembre seulement.

Veuillez me faire Monsieur.

Bien Votre en H.S. et M.C.

P.S. Contre Orme

April 26, 1941.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir-

While in Fort George recently I considered it advisable to discharge Louis Etherington from the Roman Catholic hospital with the advice that he be admitted to school where he could be under the care of the Nurse daily.

Father Couture advised me that the quota of pupils was filled but agreed to allow the boy to school asking permission to add this boy's name to the register thereby increasing the quota by one.

This request is hereby submitted for your consideration.

Yours truly,

Dr. T. J. Orford.
Ottawa,
May 6, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo in which you state that you arranged to discharge Louis Etherington from the hospital and that you placed him in the Fort George R.C. School.

In the current year's appropriation provision is made for a per capita allowance for slightly over $8 (92.24% of $20) at this school. I regret that the present setup of our appropriation does not permit our paying for any higher number than that quoted.

If the boy recently placed in the school brings the number over that mentioned above it will be advisable for you to communicate with the Assistant Superintendent of Medical Services who might be able to allow grant for the boy to June 30 at which time he could be absorbed into the number of regular, grant-earning pupils.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dr. T.J. Orford,
In Charge Indian Agency,
Moose Factory,
via Moosonee, Ont.

Dear Sir-

While in Fort George recently it was considered advisable to discharge Louis Etherington from the R. C. hospital to the R. C. school where he could be under daily treatment by the Nurse. His condition at that time did not warrant hospitalization for a longer period.

The quota of grant earning pupils at this school is filled. Under the circumstances could a grant be allowed for this boy to June 30th.

Yours truly,

OTTAWA.
Dear Bishop Belleau:

I have intended to write you for the past week or so and to state that we have not yet received the June quarter return of the Fort George R.C. School. We have received the enclosed return for September but we cannot pay September until the June quarter return is received. You will remember that in conversation with you recently I suggested that the names of all the Indian children in attendance at this school be included on these returns, although we only allow grant for slightly over 18. You will remember my reasons for suggesting this action.

I trust that you will find it possible to have the return for the quarter ended June 30, 1942, and the revised return for the September quarter, 1942, forwarded at as early a date as possible.

I believe it inadvisable to include the names of the Vestaltook children as they are Eskimos and, therefore, should not appear on the return of Indian children.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rt. Rev. H. Belleau,
Vicar Apostolic of James Bay,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, July 15, 1943.

Dear Bishop Belleau:

In preparing the return of the Fort George Residential School, which was forwarded to the Department, covering the quarter ended September 30, 1942, grant was requested for the full quarter for each of the children whose name was shown on the return. However, under the heading "Date of entrance to school", an entry was made showing that each of the children had entered the school on August 1, 1942. If that information was correct, we should have allowed grant only from August 1 to September 30. However, we were under the impression that this entry was a mistake on the part of the person who prepared the return, as I felt, from conversations we have had, that all the children had been in the school for some considerable time.

The auditor has been recently rechecking our returns and he has discovered this discrepancy. I would therefore appreciate your advising me whether the pupils whose names were shown on the return for the quarter September 30, 1942, were actually in residence from July 1, 1942.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Right Rev. H. Belleau, O.M.I.,
Moosonee, Ont.
Mr. Philip Phelan  
Chief, Training Division  
Indian Affairs Branch  
Department of Mines and Resources  
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Have received your letter re-return for Fort George Catholic School, September 1942 quarter.

Have been absent visiting missions and could not answer sooner. Mistake has been made, mentioning August 1st as date of entrance into school. Leaving for Fort George on sooner tomorrow morning. I will look into the matter and have correct return sent as soon as possible.

Thank you for notifying us about this.

Yours truly,

Ottawa,
November 22, 1943.

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of the September quarter return of the Fort George R.C. Residential School. The names of James Corston, Joseph Martinsau and Emily, Marianna and Kathleen Corston should not appear on future returns, as the Indian Agent, Dr. Orford, states that they are not Indians.

The names shown on the attached return which we are sending back should not be sent to the Indian Affairs Branch in future, as it is understood that these children are Eskimos. In this connection I would refer you to a letter written to Bishop Belleau on January 11, 1943, regarding this family.

On the June quarter return Sophie Josecomolom is shown as No. 045. This name does not appear on the September quarter return, but on the latter return Annie Kacobac is shown as No. 045. New pupils should be given new numbers and when a pupil is discharged the register number should be dropped from the return. It is very confusing to us to have the same number shown in regard to two different pupils. I trust that you will keep this suggestion in mind for the future.

Yours truly,

Rev. D. Couture, O.M.I.,
Principal,
R.C. Indian Residential School,
Fort George, Que.,
via Moosonee, Ont.

Philip Phelan,

Ecole Ste Thérèse

Le 29 février 1944.

Cher Monsieur,

En réponse à la lettre adressée au Père D.Couture datée du 22 novembre 1943, portant le No de filières 72-4-10, je tiens à vous dire que je considère les remarques fort justes.

À l'avenir donc seulement les enfants indiens (non les Métis) devront paraître sur les rapports envoyés au département des Affaires Indiennes.

Je fais remarquer que Sophie Joccomolon fut déchargée de l'école à l'été 1943, et Annie Kacobac une nouvelle élève de l'été dernier a pris le même numéro. À l'avenir donc je verrai que personne prenne le même No puisque c'est sujet à confusion dans les fiches, je comprends.

Le Docteur Crford, Agent de Moose Factory, doit venir à Fort Georges en mars. J'en profiterai pour lui donner et expliquer la dislocation de trois de nos enfants de l'école, ainsi que les feuilles d'admission et d'examen physique des nouveaux enfants de l'été 1943.

Excusez mes retards en cette matière, j'arrivai à Fort Georges le 3 octobre 1943, comme Principal de l'école, à ce moment la navigation ferme et impossible de communiquer soit avec Ottawa ou l'Agence de Moose Factory, il fallait attendre le prochain d'hiver dû à la fin de février.

Croyez à mon sincère dévouement et à la collabora-

Reverend Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, advising of your appointment as Principal of the Fort George R.C. Residential School on October 5.

It is noted that you have reviewed my letter of November 22 and that you will prepare future returns in accordance with our wishes. This will mean that Annie Kacobae will be given a new number, as the number 043 applies to Sophie Jeecoomoam, who was discharged from the school in the summer of 1943.

I also wish to thank you for the pictures of the school which are very interesting.

Ottawa,

Dr. T.J. Orford, Indian Agent, Moose Factory, Ont.

I am in receipt of a letter dated February 29 from Reverend Lionel Labreche, O.M.I., who states he took charge of the Fort George R.C. Residential School on October 3, 1945. Owing to mail difficulties he states he was unable to previously communicate either with this office or with you.

In this letter Father Labreche requests that you visit the school at an early date in order to medically examine the children. I simply pass this request on to you for whatever action you consider necessary.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Doctor,

I let you know why my daughter Dorothy is not going anymore at the School at Moore Factory? Because she hates the place. There is too much manual work in that school. Last year she has run away like many other boys & girls; you know as well as myself why her mother doesn't understand the situation.

I have put my two Boys in the R.C.M. School at East George this year because the children are very well trained there. I think it is not too late to give the same chance to my daughter.

As far as I understand the Indian act, we have freedom for hospitals and schools.
These are some of my reasons why Dorothy is not at M.S., but at F.S. I hope the Department will take them in consideration. So fare,

Yours Truly,

Philip Settland

Mr. Phelan Phelan,

Department of Mines and Resources,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Referring to your letter of the 17th instant, (72-4-10),
I beg to give following information:

Lucie Rupert for whom an application for admission to the
Fort George R.C. Residential School, has been sent, is an Indian.
It was intended that authority to receive her into the School be requested
of the Department, for reasons of moral protection and advanced vocational
training. Lucie has reached beyond school age (and she has already been a
pupil or at least has been a helper residing at the School). Of this,
however I am not certain. I am inclined to believe that she must have been
only working for the School if her name does not appear in the past returns
and if no application form has ever been filed in her name.

Thank you for approving of her admission for one year.

The children for whom attached forms had been signed by
parents or guardians are all Indians. The forms were signed while the
Father Principal of the Fort George School was on a trip to Richmond Gulf.
It appears that he either forgot the Indian Affairs application forms, or
happened to have run out of his supply, and he may have used these as a
substitute.

I regret having received your letter lately only, in Montreal.
Please address all correspondence to Moosonee, as usual.

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]
Vicar Apostolic of James Bay.

MOOSONEE, Ontario.

Dear Bishop Belleau:

The attached return for the September quarter has just been received from the Fort George R.C. School. Although the Principal did not request it, we are allowing the 62 days holiday grant for six of the pupils who were in residence to June 30, 1946 and were allowed home on holidays. This is our usual practice with all residential schools.

In spite of this fact, the return only works out at an average attendance of 14.53 and there are only the names of 18 pupils on the return. I was under the impression that you had a much larger enrollment. If the return is correct you should send it back to me so that the grant may be paid. If incorrect, you should have a revised return prepared and forwarded.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Pointe Bleue, November 26, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Tuition Grant for 4 pupils of Pointe Bleue.

Enclosed please find Application Forms for Admission in favour of the following Indian pupils of the Pointe Bleue Reserve:

1- Paul Dominique
2- Benoit Cleary
3- Raymond Boivin
4- Henri Boivin

The parents of these four children left the Pointe Bleue Reserve in September, for their hunting grounds, and do not expect to be back before May or June next year.

As there was no possibility to place the children in other Indian families for that period, they were bound to follow the family in the woods, and consequently deprived of the school during the whole year.

Without being aware of the fact, Rev. Bishop Belleau of Fort George District has communicated by phone with Rev. Father Ethier of this parish, informing that he had place for several pupils at the Fort George Residential School and arrangement has been made to send the pupils by plane. As Father Ethier has an opportunity to send the pupils by plane at a such date directly to Fort George, immediate steps have been taken by himself and the pupils were...
leaving a short time after from St Felicien.

Every family has been consulted about the matter and they were glad to see their children placed in a school for the academic year.

Few days after the departure of the pupils, Rev. Father Ethier informed me about the matter, and he told me that Bishop Belleau had arranged the case with the Department.

I have met Mr Doucet lately at his last visit here, and apparently Bishop Belleau did not communicate with your Department regarding the matter.

The enclosed Admission Forms have been filled up at Fort George and it is why the father did not sign it. I notice also that the pupils did not pass their medical examination. Before returning the Admission forms to Fort George, re Physical Examination, I have thought wise to give you some informations regarding this special case, and forward in the meantime the forms to the Dept.

Edgar Arsenault, Supt.
Pointe Bleue Agency.

I wish to report that Maurice Boivin, son of Joseph Boivin for whom you have authorized a grant of $5.00 per month for the orphanage of Immaculée Chicoutimi, has been forwarded to Fort Georges School with his brothers and sisters.

Due to his age the parents did not allow the child to go to the orphanage of Chicoutimi because being alone, he would be too lonely. The authorities of the Fort Georges School have accepted the child under their care for the amount of $5.00 per month granted for the Orphanage of Chicoutimi. Under the circumstances I have done to the best of my knowledge and I hope the Department will approve my action.

Re: Fort George RC Indian Residential School

We have your letter of the 16th instant with reference to the children being sent to the above school.

The application forms and certificates of health should be forwarded to the Department as soon as possible, because we must have them before the end of this month in order that there will be no delay in paying the per capita grant for them.

In the case of the Fort George R.C. Residential School, the per capita allowance is provided in our appropriation for 20 children, and we have no funds to pay for a larger number. Consequently, if Maurice Boivin comes within the number for which grant is provided, we will pay for him, but if he is in excess of the number for which grant is provided, no extra payment can be made.

Re: Scholl Admissions

This is to advise that 4 Indian children have been admitted to the Fort George Roman Catholic Residential School, one being from New Post Band, two from Albany Band and one from Attawapiskat Band.

I have a letter from Archdeacon Clark, with Baptismal Certificate attached, showing that George Rickard of Albany Band No. 511 was baptised in the Anglican Church. According to our records this child is shown as Church of England.

I have discussed the matter with Bishop Belleau and he informed me that this was a mixed marriage, the mother being Roman Catholic and it was the understanding of the mother that the children would be educated in the Roman Catholic faith.

Copy of letter received from Archdeacon Clark is attached hereto and is self-explanatory. I would appreciate receiving some direction from you in this regard.

J.S. Allan
Superintendent

Department of Citizenship & Immigration

Mr. J.S. Allan,
Supt. James Bay Agency,
Indian Affairs Br.
Moose Factory Ont.

Dear Mr. Allan:

The Rev. Wm. Thompson reported to me yesterday that,
the Rev. Fr. Coutier O.M.I., of Fort George, Que. has recruited for
the R.C. School, one George Walter Rickard, son or Cornelius and
Janet Rickard. I attach the transcript of the Baptism of the same
George Walter Rickard.

As there is very little chance of bringing the boy
back to Moose at this late date I would suggest he be transferred
to the Anglican Boarding School at Fort George.

Your's sincerely;

(Sgd.) Neville R. Clarke

Mr. J.S. Allan,

Moose Factory, Ont.,

Attached I am returning the September Quarterly Return for the Fort George R.C. Indian Residential School.

The Principal has failed to separate the boys from the girls on his Return. This is usually done by indicating the register number for girls with a "G" preceding the number. Please bring this to Father Couture's attention for future returns.

Pupils 086-091 and 65-85 are entered on the Return for the first time. It is presumed that these are new admissions. However, this information should have been shown on Form I.A. 411 which is to accompany the Return itself. Furthermore, the Principal has claimed full grant of ninety-two days for each of these pupils while they entered the school during the months of August and September. It will be necessary for Father Couture to adjust either the figures or the dates of entrance to the school.

Father Couture has also dropped from the September Return the names of a number of pupils who were shown as grant-earning pupils in June. In cases of this nature the school is entitled to sixty-two days grant for each pupil. It will be necessary for the Principal to insert the names of these children and claim this grant when re-submitting his September Return.
In order to avoid financial difficulties, we are forwarding the school a part payment of $2000, on the September grant.

It would be appreciated if this Return could be corrected and returned as soon as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DEPUTY MINISTER

With reference to our telephone conversation regarding the letter from Bishop Marsh, I submit the following information:

Fort George R.C. Residential School

Enclosed is a list of the children who, the Church of England claim, should not be enrolled at the Fort George R.C. Residential School. You will note that two of them, Lily Spencer and Jackeline Loutitt, are not shown on the quarterly return from the school and consequently no grant is being paid for them.

We have an application form for each of the other eight children. The form is signed by the parent in each case and approved by Superintendent Allan. The application form states that their religion is "Christian". Per capita grant is being paid for these.

Aklavik R.C. Residential School

A careful review has been made of the returns from both the Aklavik R.C. Residential School and the Aklavik C.E. Residential School. We have been unable to locate any correspondence protesting against the admission of certain children to the R.C. School on religious grounds.

Director.

Dear Mr. Allan:

I acknowledge receipt of and thank you for your letter of the 11th ultimo. It deals with the deleting from our quarterly grant, for nine pupils of the Fort George R.C. Residential School, of the names of those pupils, on the grounds of a technical defect in the Application forms for admission. Those forms of Application for admission into the school, were written by the Principal, and signed by the Indian parents, who were supposed to be conversant with the Application which they signed. The religion of those nine pupils is put down under the name "Christian"; it has been done in this manner, with the use of that term, since 1938, for quite a few pupils. No objection was raised by any official of the Department, against the use of that term, "Christian", so far. No one ever argued that it was improper and that it rendered the child whose father signed the Application, ineligible for a grant to the school. Seven out of the nine children mentioned above, are Catholics.

The fact that Protestant parents have requested that their children be admitted, and that their direction has been given by writing, does not invalidate the right of the school to receive a per capita grant but rather agrees with Section 117 of the Indian Act, and also with another document which should not be ignored by the Canadian Federal Government, even if Indians are concerned.

I beg to quote part of the Universal Declaration of the Rights of Man, adhered to by Canada, and signed on the 10th of December 1948, by Canada's representative or delegate, at a meeting of the United Nations Organization. It stresses the elementary freedom claimed by the Indian who signs an Application for admission of his child into our Residential School, at Fort George. I wish you would, when opportunity offers itself, show this text to those who object, when an Indian parent directs that his child should go to such or such a school, and so directs in black and white. This is from Section (or Article) 26 of the Universal Declaration of the Rights of Man: "Parents have, through priority, the right to choose the kind of education to be given to their children." If they wish to have their children educated under the same religious auspices as they themselves have been educated, all is well in this respect, and the State should take this wish into account. But if, on the other hand...
for a sound reason, parents wish to have their children enter into a school of another Christian denomination, why should the State interfere and treat them as morons, unable to make a choice?

Your having been notified by Mr. Phelan himself, that the grant was cancelled for the nine above-mentioned children, makes it necessary for me to write him about it. Thank you. With kind regards.

(Signed) Henry Belleau, O.M.I.

The rulings handed down on disputed religious cases were to the effect that where a mother is Roman Catholic and the father is Protestant, the children should attend a Roman Catholic school. In cases where children were in a Protestant school and it was proven during the academic year that these children should not be in a Protestant school but should be placed in a Roman Catholic school, it was ruled in the case of the Yellowhorse children "Old Sun's, Crowfoot schools", that the children must remain in the school they are attending to the end of the academic year and then transfer effective September 1st the following academic year.

In view of the above ruling, it was decided to allow the Principal of the Fort George R.C. Residential School to claim grant for the nine children who were brought to the school on August 15, 1951 and for whom the applications for admission were disputed due to the fact that the religious denomination was shown as "Christian".

[signature], Pupil No. [number],
of the Saint Theresa Indian Residential School at Fort George,
who died at Fort George (place) on 9th of July 1947.

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

MEMORANDUM TO:

MAJOR MacKAY,

A week or so ago, Mr. Ross of the Engineering and Construction Services of the former Department of Mines and Resources called at this office and discussed, in the presence of Mr. Pauze, Indian Superintendent, who was in Ottawa at the time, the relative merits and costs of providing water to the new Seven Islands Indian Reserve and the Department's buildings thereon. Mr. Ross was of the opinion that it would be preferable to take water from a creek about 1/2 mile from the Reserve. He reported that the water in this creek had been analyzed and that it was excellent water. It had a clear colour, contained no sand or iron, was extremely soft, and had no harmful chemicals. Mr. Ross has the chemical analysis of the water, if it is required.

Following is a rough estimate of the cost of providing water by drilling wells and taking water from a creek:

Water from Wells:

4 gravel wall wells estimated at 150 ft. in depth, including drilling and casing and gravel wall around water area $ 4,000
Mechanical pumps for each well, consisting of gas engine or electric motor (deep well turbine pump) 6,000
Pressure tanks, etc. - $3,000 each 12,000
4 pump houses - $2,500 each 10,000
Contingencies 3,000
Possible cost of distribution system to Administration buildings and school 5,000
Possible freight charges 2,000

$ 42,000

Cont'd.....
Water from Creek:

Dam at intake and pumping station $2,000
1000 ft. of 4" main to reservoir 2,500
Reservoir and pump house 6,000
4000 ft. of 6" distribution main 12,000
5 hydrants, valves, etc. 2,000
3 pumps, pressure tank, etc. (1 pump at dam, 1 pump at reservoir, and 1 fire pump) 7,000
Freight 1,000
Contingencies 3,500
Possible cost of pipe line to school 10,000
Freight on pipe, additional to above freight 2,000

$48,000

From the foregoing, it will be seen that by taking the water from the creek, we would have an assured supply and the cost would not be very much greater than would be involved by securing water from four wells. Mr. Ross stated that the water in the well at the airport contained too much iron, and the water was not very good. At the present time, while a 75 gallon per minute pump was installed, it was only operating 1/3 capacity, possibly due to sand clogging the screens. Mr. Ross feels that, if we install pumps in wells, we will encounter the same difficulty, and there will be constant expense by having to replace pumps.

The foregoing figures are very rough and we were uncertain just where the school was to be located. Mr. Ross was to attend a meeting in Mr. Buck's office the next day, as Mr. Buck and Col. Neary were to discuss further the location of the school. This Section has not yet been informed as to what decision was arrived at.

Do you consider that it would be in order to ask Mr. Ross to furnish us with his report on this subject, as he has already investigated the matter on the ground. If we do not have this report, another engineer will have to visit Seven Islands to gather the information already in the possession of Mr. Ross. I have prepared the attached memorandum in case you wish to send it to the Director of Development Services, Resources and Development Department.

W. J. F. Pratt,
General Executive Assistant.

With further reference to my telephone conversation of today, I am attaching hereto a letter which Mr. Pauze gave me on my recent trip to Seven Islands.

At the present time chestnut coal is selling in Seven Islands for $38.00 per ton, and with your school being approximately eleven miles from the existing townsite I would estimate that it would cost approximately $2.50 per ton for delivery, making the cost over $40.00 per ton.

I am not sure whether you are aware of the fact that Imperial Oil and British America Oil have tank installations at Seven Islands, and the selling price of oil is approximately the same as the City rates, 18¢ per gallon. I am sure you will find it much more economical to install an oil unit for the purpose of heating this building.

My only purpose in writing this letter is to pass along this information to you, and if you decide to install an oil unit instead of a coal stoker we would appreciate being advised as soon as possible, as it may make some little difference in our tender price, as we are bidding this project.

Dear Father Plourde:

Seven Islands Residential School

You will recall our previous discussion concerning the fuel for this school.

You will be interested in a letter which I have received from our Indian Superintendent at Seven Islands. In this letter he points out that at the present time chestnut coal is selling in Seven Islands for $38. a ton. With the distance of the school from the townsite, it is estimated that it would cost approximately $2. a ton for delivery making the cost about $40. a ton.

At Seven Islands, Imperial Oil Company and British American Oil have tank installations and the selling price of oil is approximately the same rate as city rates namely 18½ cents a gallon. It is felt that it might be more economical to install an oil unit for the purpose of heating this building.

I would appreciate, therefore, your passing this information to the Reverend Bishop as this may result in his requesting a change in the heating plant. I am sending this letter to you in duplicate in the event that you may wish to forward a copy to him.

He indicated that his contracting experience had been mostly highway work and forestry or logging operations, but referred to a school smaller but similar in character to the proposed Seven Islands building, designed by Pierre Rinfret of Quebec, and which cost in the neighborhood of $152,000.00.

Tremblay stated he would have as his engineer in charge, Mr. Lionel Halle of Quebec City, and named Messrs Raoul Tremblay, of Portneuf and Georges Dechene of Quebec, as superintendents.

Following receipt of Tremblay's telegram, a letter signed by Mr. Pratt under date of the 27th of May last, requested confirmation of the information supplied, in response to which comment is furnished as follows:

Although Tremblay indicates a standing as a general contractor, his experience on buildings appears to be limited. The school at Portneuf Quebec built for their Board of Education was discussed with the designing architect who stated that the work was satisfactory. Mr. Rinfret does not know who was the Superintendent of the school, but says Tremblay's building operations are not extensive, there is little likelihood of having the same staff employed at Seven Islands. One building, however, is not sufficient reference on which to base a reputation, and Mr. Rinfret is reported from other sources, to have carried out very few inspections. (a) Mr. Lionel Halle is a pensioned ex-employee of the Federal Department of Public Works, who was in the past located at Quebec, but who now is not prepared to assume the duties of an Engineer-in-Charge of a large structural undertaking. He would be willing to establish the location and set levels for the school if requested, but this duty can be carried out by the Departmental Supervising Architect.

(b) Mr. Raoul Tremblay of Portneuf Quebec, a relative of Lucien Tremblay, was described as a fair carpenter, but not possessing the qualifications of a superintendent.

(c) Mr. Georges Dechene of Quebec, was described as a man who might be used as a labour foreman but not in the capacity of either superintendent or assistant superintendent.

Without a more intimate knowledge of Tremblay's organization, the writer is not prepared to recommend the award of a contract to Lucien Tremblay.

When tenders were invited, the invitation, in the form of an advertisement, appeared in selected newspapers from the 30th day of March 1950, until the 4th of April, 1950. The set time for closing tenders in Ottawa, was noon on the 24th of April, allowing three full weeks for the preparation of tenders. Five bona-fide lump sum tenders reached Ottawa within the time limit, but on the morning of the 24th of April, a telegram was received by the Director, Development Services Branch, from M.L. Coiteux, President of Sept Iles Development and Construction Co. Ltd., stating that a tender on the project had been mailed from Quebec that morning for special delivery. Mr. Coiteux understood that if his tender was postmarked as of the 24th of April, 1950, it would receive consideration with any others.

Mr. Coiteux's understanding was in error, and consequently his tender cannot be considered. Under normal circumstances, all tenders deserving consideration must be opened at the same time.

As a matter of record, all tenders must be submitted in the addressed envelope supplied by the Department for the purpose, which upon arrival in Ottawa, are not identifiable, and for that reason, cannot be returned to the tenderers. All sealed tenders must nevertheless be opened, the security deposit removed, registered and placed in safekeeping. When opened, the tender from the Sept Iles Development and Construction Co. Ltd., was in the amount of $348,176.00, the second lowest. It must be stated however, that our report on this organization would not justify the undersigned in recommending the award of a contract to them, even had the tender been received within the time limit. The security deposit forwarded with the tender has been returned to this firm.

The second lowest bona-fide tender was submitted by the North Shore Construction Co. Ltd., with headquarters at Montreal. It was in the amount of $359,450.00, $47,500.00 higher than the lowest tenderer. This firm an affiliate of Clan Steamships Ltd., has carried out the construction of a number of housing developments, and other building work for pulp and paper companies, and have also
completed a number of dock construction contracts, much of the latter for the Dominion Government. They have also erected an agent's residence, and an office building for this Department at the Seven Islands Indian Agency. The Department of Public Works consider their work satisfactory and while not of major proportions, the work performed for our Department is well executed.

It is felt that, the Department's interests would best be served by the award of a contract to the North Shore Construction Co. Ltd.

If concurrence is received, a submission to Council will be prepared immediately for our Minister's signature, seeking authority to initiate action with that firm.
